para.text: An individual may not engage in the inspection of an on-site sewage disposal system for property transfer inspections after June 30, 2022, without obtaining an on-site wastewater property transfer inspection license issued by the Department.
The Department may issue an on-site wastewater property transfer inspection license to an individual that:
Submits a complete application provided by the Department for licensure to the Department;
Submits the $150 application fee; and
Either:
Provides a certificate of completion for a Department-approved training course meeting the requirements detailed in Regulation .04 of this chapter; or
As of July 1, 2022, is identified on MDE’s list of individuals who have completed a Department-approved on-site inspection course for property transfer inspections.
The on-site wastewater property transfer inspection license will be valid for a 2-year period.

Sixty days prior to expiration of an on-site wastewater property transfer inspection license, an individual shall apply for licensure renewal according to the conditions described in §B of this regulation.
The licensee shall retain all records of property transfer inspections for a period of 5 years and provide copies of these records to the Department upon request.
The Department reserves the right to suspend or revoke a license in accordance with Regulation .06 of this chapter.
A training course for an on-site wastewater property transfer inspection license shall include:
A minimum 14 total hours of instruction to include lectures, demonstrations, and course review;
A minimum of 3 hours of the 14 hours shall include hands-on training which allows applicants the experience of performing tasks associated with on-site wastewater sewage system inspections;
Topics covering Maryland statutory and regulatory requirements related to on-site sewage disposal systems in COMAR 26.04.02;
Distribution of written materials, including the Department standard inspection form and instruction guideline document; and
A closed book examination with a minimum of 100 multiple choice questions with:
25 questions specific to COMAR 26.04.02;
15 questions specific to the Department standard inspection form; and
10 questions specific to final inspection determinations regarding replacement or repair to an on-site wastewater system.
Applicants may receive a certificate of completion when passing an examination with a 70 percent or greater score.
Any training course for the purpose of obtaining a certificate of completion under this regulation shall be provided by the Department or a Department-approved training course provider.
The training course provider must satisfy all requirements of Regulation .04 of this chapter.

The Department may approve a training course if the training provider demonstrates to the satisfaction of the Department the ability to teach the requirements in this regulation and Regulations .02—.04 of this chapter by:
Submitting complete course materials to the Department for approval; and
Employing instructors having academic credentials or a minimum of 3 years field experience in the topics they instruct.
The training provider shall administer a proctored closed-book examination approved by the Department which:
Contains a minimum of 100 multiple-choice questions, of which:
At least 25 questions shall be specific to COMAR 26.04.02;
At least 15 questions shall adequately cover the Department standard inspection format; and
At least 10 questions shall adequately cover final determinations regarding replacement or repair of an on-site wastewater system inspection; and
Requires a passing score of at least 70 percent for certificate of completion.
The training provider shall issue to each individual who successfully completes the training course a certificate of completion with the following information:
Name of training course;
Individual’s name;
Individual’s mailing address, electronic address, and phone number;
Identification number unique to that individual;
Name, address, and phone number of training provider;
Instructor’s name and signature; and
Date of training and examination.
In order to audit any training provider, Department representatives may attend, evaluate, and monitor any training course and may or may not provide notice of attendance.
Prior to changing any portion of an approved course the training provider shall obtain approval from the Department for the proposed changes.
A training provider shall provide to the Department a written schedule of dates and locations at which training will be conducted and:
Ensure that the Department receives this schedule at least 10 days before the course is offered; and
Provide as promptly as possible to the Department any changes to the schedule.
The training provider shall:
Maintain lists of individuals trained, the dates on which training occurred, instructor names, proctor names, training locations, individual test scores, and copies of certificates of completion;
Maintain testing materials in a secure and confidential manner and, if any breach occurs with testing materials, notify the Department within 48 hours;
Retain records for 3 years and provide copies of these records to the Department upon request; and
Send the information in §H(1) of this regulation on a form provided by the Department to the Department within 10 working days of completion of the approved course.
Training courses shall be approved annually by the Department.
Training providers shall provide reasonable testing accommodations upon request from an individual.
Unless the Department withdraws the approval of the training provider or a training course such approval shall remain valid for 1 year.
Training courses approvals are not transferable.

The Department may withdrawal the approval of any approved training course or training provider if the Department determines that the training provider, instructors, or course has demonstrated any of the following:
Failure to meet the standards of this regulation;
Misrepresentation of a training course’s approval;
Failure of instructors to present the course as approved;
Failure to submit any notifications required by this chapter in a timely manner;
Failure to maintain records as required by this chapter;
Falsification of records, instructor qualifications or other information;
Incompetence or negligent in the performance of administering the training or the exam; or
Other good cause.

The Department shall serve notice of withdrawal of an approved training provider or an approved training course. The training provider may request a hearing within 10 days after service of the notice. If the Department receives a timely request, the Department shall hold a hearing in accordance with State Government Article, §10-201 et seq., Annotated Code of Maryland.

para.text: In this chapter, the following terms have the meanings indicated.
Terms Defined.
“Act” means Housing and Community Development Article, §4-509, Annotated Code of Maryland.
“Anchor institution” means:
An institution of higher education in the State, including departments, foundations, and other entities of the institution; or
A hospital institution in the State, including departments, foundations, and other entities of the institution that:
Has a group of at least five physicians who are organized as a medical staff for the institution;
Maintains facilities to provide, under the supervision of the medical staff, diagnostic and treatment services for two or more unrelated individuals; and
Admits or retains the individuals for overnight care.
“Application” means an application to the Department as described in Regulation .05 of this chapter.

“Blighted area” means an area in which a majority of buildings have declined in productivity by reason of obsolescence, depreciation, or other causes to an extent that they no longer justify fundamental repairs and adequate maintenance.
“Department” means the Department of Housing and Community Development, a principal department of the State.
“Financial assistance” means a grant or a loan.
“Fund" means the Seed Community Development Anchor Institution Fund established under Housing and Community Development Article, §4-509, Annotated Code of Maryland.
“Matching funds” means funds that are contributed to the project in an amount that equals the amount of financial assistance received from the Fund.
“Program” means the Seed Community Development Anchor Institution Program established under the provisions of the Act.
“Project” means a project submitted by an anchor institution to the Secretary for approval in accordance with the Act and this chapter.
“Recipient of financial assistance” means an anchor institution approved by the Department to receive financial assistance under the Program.
“Secretary” means the Secretary of Housing and Community Development.
“Sustainable community” means an area designated as a sustainable community under Housing and Community Development Article, §6–205, Annotated Code of Maryland.
A recipient of financial assistance shall meet the following minimum requirements:
Be an anchor institution;
Not have defaulted on any prior financial assistance from the Department;
Not be currently barred or suspended from any of the Department's programs;
Have the legal capacity and all necessary legal authority to incur the obligations involved in the form of financial assistance provided under the Program; and
Be in good standing and qualified to do business in Maryland.
Financial assistance may be used for any costs and expenses related to community development projects in sustainable communities or in blighted areas of the State.

A recipient of financial assistance may grant or lend all or a portion of the financial assistance it receives from the Program to a designated third party to carry out the project in accordance with the terms and conditions of an agreement with the Department.
Applications for financial assistance shall be accepted in one or more competitive rounds to be announced by the Department annually.
An application submitted to the Department shall:
Be on standard forms prescribed by the Department;
Be submitted by an applicant that meets the requirements of Regulation .03A of this chapter;
Be for a project that is located within a sustainable community or within a blighted area;
State the amount and type of financial assistance requested;
Provide a comprehensive description of the applicant and project including:
The public purpose of the project and the needs of the community that will be served;
A projected timeline for implementation of the project;
The ability of the applicant to carry out the proposed project in accordance with the projected timeline;
Other public and private resources available for implementing the project; and
The social and economic benefits created by the project;

Provide a budget, in a form acceptable to the Department, that at a minimum shows anticipated project costs and expenses, anticipated sources of project revenue, and identification of the revenues that can be used to repay the financial assistance provided by the program if provided as a loan;

Propose benchmarks for evaluating whether the proposed project results in a desired outcome for the sustainable community or blighted area, such as community stabilization or reversing economic, social, and physical decline of the community in which the project is located;
Describe any public input the applicant has received on the proposed project, including the nature and extent of the public support for or in opposition to the proposed project;

Demonstrate that, upon completion, the project will be in compliance with all applicable zoning requirements and standards as well as the applicable building code of the local jurisdiction in which the project is located;
Demonstrate the ability to gain site control if applicable to the project through ownership, leasehold interest, contract, option or other agreement satisfactory to the Department;

Provide evidence that the applicant has matching funds available for the project in the amounts required by Housing and Community Development Article, §4-509(g)(2), Annotated Code of Maryland, or in the competitive application round announcement;

Describe whether historic properties or districts will be impacted and how the applicant will comply with the requirements of State Finance and Procurement Article, §§5A-325—5A-326, Annotated Code of Maryland, and Financial Institutions Article, §13-1112(b), Annotated Code of Maryland; and
Include other information or documentation the Department may require.
An application for financial assistance may be submitted to fund one or more projects.
A recipient of financial assistance may file one or more applications in accordance with schedules established by the Department.
The Department shall determine whether information required under Regulation .04 of this chapter is contained in the application.
All complete applications will be competitively evaluated by the Department on a point basis, which shall include the following criteria:
Capacity of the applicant to carry out the project;
Community context;
Public purpose;
Leveraging and cost-effectiveness;
Geographic distribution;
Unique or time-sensitive projects;
Revitalization needs of the community;
Economic development and revitalization opportunities created by the project; and
Other factors established by the Department in the competitive round announcement.
The Department, in its discretion, may:
Accept public input on an application;
Request from the applicant additional information concerning an application, including oral presentations; and
Refer the application to other State agencies, as the Department considers appropriate, to undertake the analysis of the application.
Upon the Department’s completion of the review and scoring of the applications, the Department shall make a recommendation to the Secretary on the applications.
Upon receipt of the Department's recommendation, the Secretary:
May request additional information from the applicant or Department concerning the application, including oral presentations;
May give priority to applications that provide for the likely repayment of the financial assistance; and
Shall act on the application by approving it, disapproving it, or approving it with modifications.
If the Secretary determines not to approve all or part of an application, the Department shall issue a written notice of denial.
Reconsideration.

An applicant may request initial reconsideration of a denial by submitting a written request to the Department, which must be received by the Department within 30 days following the date of the denial notice.
The request for reconsideration shall address each reason for the denial and provide documentation supporting reasons for reconsideration of the application.
The Department shall respond in writing to the applicant's request for reconsideration within 90 days of receipt by the Department of the request for reconsideration.
An initial decision or reconsideration of a decision is not a contested case within the meaning of the Administrative Procedure Act or COMAR 05.01.01.02.

section.heading: Nondiscrimination; Drug and Alcohol Free Workplace.

para.text: A recipient of financial assistance may not discriminate on the basis of race, color, religion, national origin, sex, marital status, physical or mental disability, sexual orientation, or age, except with regard to age as permitted under the federal Housing for Older Persons Act, as amended from time to time, or other similar federal laws, in any aspect of the Program, or in any aspect of employment by any recipient of financial assistance in connection with any project financed or assisted under the Program.

A recipient of financial assistance shall comply with all applicable federal, State, and local laws and Department policies and programs regarding discrimination and equal opportunity in employment, housing, credit practices, and drug and alcohol free workplaces, including:
Titles VI and VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, as amended;
Title VIII of the Civil Rights Acts of 1968, as amended;
The Fair Housing Amendments Act of 1988, as amended;
State Government Article, Title 20, Annotated Code of Maryland, as amended;
The Department’s Minority Business Enterprise Program, as amended;
The Governor’s Executive Order 01.01.1989.18, Drug and Alcohol Free Workplace, and any Department or State regulations adopted or to be adopted to carry out the requirements of that Order; and
The Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990, as amended.
Covenants implementing these requirements, including affirmative action measures, shall be included in appropriate agreements between the Department and the recipient of financial assistance.

An individual may not knowingly make or cause to be made a false statement or report in any document required to be furnished to the Secretary or the Department by an agreement relating to financial assistance.
An individual who violates §A of this regulation is subject to immediate cancellation or acceleration of the financial assistance provided by the Program and any other penalties authorized by law.

para.text: In this chapter, the following terms have the meanings indicated.
Terms Defined.
Adulterated Food.
“Adulterated food” has the meaning stated in Health-General Article, §21-207, Annotated Code of Maryland.
“Adulterated food” includes food that is:
Is diseased;
Is contaminated;
Is filthy;
Is putrid;
Has decomposed;
Contains any poisonous or otherwise deleterious substance that, in the quantity present, reasonably would be expected to make it injurious to health;
Contains any food additive or color additive, the particular use of which has not been found safe as provided under Health-General Article, §21-239, Annotated Code of Maryland;
Was produced, prepared, packed, or held under unsanitary conditions that reasonably would be expected to have contaminated it with filth;
Was produced, prepared, packed, or held under unsanitary conditions that reasonably would be expected to have caused it to be diseased, unwholesome, or injurious to health;
Was packaged in a container composed of any poisonous or otherwise deleterious substance that reasonably would be expected to have caused the food to be injurious to health; or
Is misbranded so that the food is unsafe for human consumption.
“Allergen cross-contact” means the unintentional incorporation of a food allergen into a food that has not been identified as containing it.
“Approving authority” means the agency designated in the laws of another state or country to license or permit a food processing plant.
“Approved source” means a source of food or food ingredients accepted by the Department because the food or food ingredients from the source:
Are not adulterated foods or misbranded as defined in §B(1) and (21) of this regulation; and
Where required, are regulated by the approving authority.

“Charity deer processing” means the processing of legally harvested whitetail deer into cuts of raw meat as only a service for a charitable organization that donates the meat to the needy for consumption.
“Contamination” means the process or state that potentially renders a food unsafe for human consumption due to the adulteration of the food with:
Pathogens;
Chemicals;
Allergens;
Foreign objects; or
Filth.
“Corrective action” means the documented steps taken when a deviation occurs at a control point to:
Address the cause of the deviation;
Restore control; and
Prevent the affected food from entering commerce.
“Critical control point” means a step or procedure in a food process at which control can be applied, and is essential to:
Prevent a food safety hazard;
Eliminate a food safety hazard; or
Reduce a hazard to an acceptable level.
Critical Item.
“Critical item” means a food safety requirement that if violated requires:
Immediate correction;
The cessation of some or all processing operations; or
Plant closure.
“Critical item” includes the following requirements:
Food is obtained from an approved source;
Food is protected from contamination and allergen cross-contact;
Food processes provide safe food with proper control at critical control points;
Food is protected by ensuring that all personnel wash hands thoroughly as often as necessary to prevent food contamination by hand contact;
Personnel are restricted from food handling positions or the plant as indicated if they have an illness or infection that is transmissible through food as defined in COMAR 10.06.01.06E;
Food is packaged and labeled for safety with allergens properly identified on the label;
A sufficient volume of potable hot and cold water supply under pressure is available; and
Sewage is discharged in compliance with applicable laws and regulations.
“Department” means the Maryland Department of Health or the Department's designee.
Farm.
“Farm” means a place where agricultural commodities are grown, raised, or harvested for commercial purposes.
“Farm” includes a place where, for commercial purposes:
Crops are grown and harvested;
Fruit, nuts, or other agricultural commodities are harvested from trees; or
Animals are raised, fed, and managed for meat or other agricultural commodities.
“Food” means:
Articles used for food or drink for humans or other animals;
Chewing gum; and
Individual components of such articles.
“Food allergen” means an ingredient that contains protein derived from one of the following foods or food groups:
Milk;
Egg;
Fish;
Crustacean shellfish;
Tree nuts;
Wheat;
Peanuts;
Soybeans; or
Sesame.
Food Processing Plant.
“Food processing plant” means a place used for or in connection with commercial food:
Manufacturing;
Processing;
Packing;
Repacking;
Storage; or
Distribution.
“Food processing plant” includes a:
Crab meat picking plant;
Food manufacturing plant;
Cold food warehouse;
Ambient food warehouse, except as specified in §B(14)(c) of this regulation;
Shellfish plant or dealer;
Bottled water plant;

Meat processing plant or poultry processing plant that is not subject to regulation by the United States Department of Agriculture or by a meat inspection program or poultry inspection program administered by the Maryland Department of Agriculture;
Cider plant;
Charity deer processing plant; and
Producer mobile farmer’s market unit.
“Food processing plant” does not include a warehouse or distribution center that:
Stores only sealed containers pre-packaged, ready-to-eat snack foods that do not require temperature control for safety;
Stores only bottled beverages that do not require temperature control for safety;
Stores only packaged ice;
Stores only whole bean, ground or instant coffee, or leaf or instant teas;
Stores only nondairy dehydrated whiteners, sugar, or sugar-free sweeteners; or
Is a food transfer station where food is transferred between transportation vehicles or there is an area maintained for food that is stored for less than 24 hours.
“Generally recognized as safe (GRAS)” means that a substance is:
Not harmful to humans consuming the substance under the intended conditions of use; and
In accordance with 21 CFR §170.30.
“Hazard” means any biological, chemical (including radiological), or physical agent that has the potential to cause illness or injury

“Hazard Analysis Critical Control Point (HACCP)” means a management system that addresses the safety of food that is temperature controlled for safety (TCS) at critical control points as specified by:
COMAR 10.15.10 Procedures for the Safe Handling and Processing of Seafood;
COMAR 10.15.12 Procedures for the Safe Handling and Processing of Juice;
21 CFR Part 123 Fish and Fishery Products; or
The National Advisory Committee on the Microbiological Criteria for Food.
“Indirect food additive” means a substance that is unintentionally incorporated into food due to processing, holding, or packaging.
“Label” means a display of written or graphic matter on the container, other than the package liner, of a food.
“Labeling” means any label or other written or graphic material that:
Is on a:
Food;
Food container; or
Food wrapping; or
Accompanies a food.
“Misbranded” has the meaning stated in Health-General Article, §21-210, Annotated Code of Maryland.
“Person-in-charge” means:
The licensee; or
Another person responsible for the operation of the food processing plant.
“Potable water” means a water supply that meets the requirements of the Safe Drinking Water Act, as administered by the EPA and COMAR 26.04.02.01B(33).
“Poultry” means any domesticated bird.
Preventive Controls.
“Preventive controls” means a step or combination of steps that are taken to minimize, prevent, or eliminate:
Identified food safety hazards; or
Food safety hazards that are reasonably likely to occur.
“Preventive controls” includes:
Process controls;
Allergen controls;
Sanitation controls; and
Other appropriate controls taken at critical control points or at other points as necessary to ensure food safety based on the outcome of a hazard analysis.
“Preventive controls qualified individual (PCQI)” means an individual who has:
Successfully completed training in the development and application of risk-based preventive controls; or
The education, experience, and knowledge to develop and implement a food safety system.
“Principal display panel” means the part of a label that is the most likely to be displayed, presented, shown, or examined under customary conditions of display for retail sale.
“Process” means a specific set of operations or procedures used to manufacture a food.
“Process authority” means an individual having expert knowledge of specialized food processes acquired through :
Training; and
Experience.
Producer Mobile Farmer’s Market Unit.
“Producer mobile farmer’s market unit” means a unit designed to ensure that food is:
Protected from contamination during transportation from farm to farmer’s market or public festival or event; and
Kept at temperatures that support the safety and wholesomeness of the food.
“Producer mobile farmer’s market unit” does not include a unit used to deliver:
Prepackaged foods to fill an order of a customer;
Raw agricultural products; or
On-farm home processed foods that do not require temperature control for safety.

“Qualified auditor” means a qualified individual with necessary technical expertise regarding hazards being controlled to evaluate food safety regulations and review a supplier’s written plan, for example, the Hazard Analysis and Critical Control Point (HACCP) plan or other food safety plan, and its implementation through:
Education;
Training; or
Experience.
“Qualified individual” means a person who is able to handle food safely as appropriate to the individual’s assigned duties, as determined by having the:
Education;
Training; or
Experience.

“Scheduled process means a method or set of procedures established by a process authority for processing a food, includes the critical factors that may impact the food’s safety or stability to achieve and maintain a food that will not permit the growth of microorganisms having public health significance.

“Shelf life study” means a food evaluation using microbiological, physical, chemical, organoleptic, or other tests to determine the length of time a food may be stored before the food becomes unfit for sale or human consumption.
“Shell eggs” means raw or treated eggs produced by poultry for human consumption.
“Snack foods” means chips, pretzels, candy, and other novelty snacks.
“Temperature control for safety (TCS)” means a food requires specific time and temperature control to limit pathogenic microorganism growth or toxin formation for safety.

section.heading: Compliance with Other Chapters.
section.text: The person-in-charge shall manufacture, process, pack/repack, label, store, or distribute food and design, operate, and maintain a food processing plant and the facilities and equipment associated with a food processing plant in compliance with this chapter and with COMAR 10.15.01, 10.15.02, 10.15.07, 10.15.10, and 10.15.12, as applicable.

para.text: Individuals do not cause contamination of:
Food;
Food-contact surfaces; and
Food-packaging material;
Individuals are excluded from working with food, food-contact surfaces, and food-packaging materials:
As provided in COMAR 10.06.01.06E; and
When an individual has an:
Illness transmissible through food; or
Exposed and open sore or cut;
Individuals working in direct contact with food, food-contact surfaces, and food-packaging material:
Wear suitable, clean outerwear garments in a manner that protects the food, food-contact surfaces, and food-packaging material against contamination;
Wear hair nets, beard covers, or other effective hair restraints;
Keep fingernails clean and neatly trimmed;
Prevent fingernail polish or artificial fingernails from coming into contact with food, food-contact surfaces, and food-packaging material;
Remove all unsecured jewelry and other objects that may fall into food, equipment, or containers;
Secure any jewelry that cannot be removed with material which can be maintained in an intact, clean, and sanitary condition;
Wash hands and exposed arm areas thoroughly with soap and warm water:
At a hand washing facility in compliance with regulation .12G of this chapter;
Before starting work;
After each absence from the workstation; and
At any other time when hands may have become soiled or contaminated or as often as required to remove soil and contamination; and
Apply sanitizer as necessary to protect against contamination with undesirable microorganisms;
Individuals wearing gloves while working with food or food-contact surfaces shall:
Use gloves that are intended for food contact;
Maintain gloves in an intact, clean, and sanitary condition;
Wash hands thoroughly before putting on gloves;
Clean and sanitize reusable gloves using approved methods or equipment.
Replace gloves:
When the gloves are damaged or soiled;
Between unrelated tasks; and
After an interruption in working with food or food-contact surfaces;
Individuals store personal items in a designated area other than where food is exposed or stored, or where equipment or utensils are washed;
Individuals do not use tobacco, chew gum, eat food, drink beverages, or engage in any activity that might contaminate food in an area that is used for:
Food processing;
Equipment or utensil washing;
Storage of:
Food;
Food-contact surfaces; or
Food packaging;
Individuals prevent allergen cross-contact and contamination with microorganisms, deleterious substances, or foreign matter of food, food-contact surfaces, and food-packaging materials;

Education and training in personal hygiene, food handling, and plant sanitation is provided to personnel, food handlers, and supervisors in a language and form they understand as it relates to assigned duties such that:
Each individual engaged in food handling or in the supervision of one or more individuals be qualified by:
Education;
Training;
Experience; or
A combination of education, training, and experience;
Responsibility for education and training shall be clearly assigned to qualified supervisory personnel; and
Records that document each individual’s training are maintained according to Regulation .06 of this chapter; and

When specialized personnel training is required by COMAR 10.15.01, 10.15.02, 10.15.07, 10.15.10, or 10.15.12 or this chapter, or 21 CFR Part 112, Subpart M, the specialized training is obtained as required.
All food and food ingredients processed in a food processing plant:
Are from an approved source;
Are GRAS;
If applicable, conform to a standard of identity, as defined in 21 CFR Part 130;
Comply with FDA regulations for poisonous or deleterious substances; and
Are identified and held in a manner that prevents allergen cross-contact if the food and food ingredients are an allergen or contain an allergen;
When ice is used in contact with food, it shall be:
Made from potable water; and
Manufactured and stored in accordance with this chapter;
Compressed air or other gasses mechanically introduced into food do not contaminate the food with unlawful indirect food additives;
Raw materials and other ingredients:
Are inspected at receipt to ensure that they are acceptable for use; and
Are washed or cleaned as necessary to remove soil or other contamination;
Food is processed and stored under conditions and control procedures that prevent and protect from:
Contamination; and
Allergen cross-contact;
The potential for contamination and allergen cross-contact is reduced by:
Food safety controls;
Operating practices; and
Separation of operations by:
Location;
Time; or
Effective design;
Food is processed and stored at temperatures that:
Minimize the potential for the growth of microorganisms; and
Prevent adulteration;
The thermal processing of food eliminates or reduces the number of pathogens in the food so that the food is safe for human consumption;
The cooling of foods is conducted using methods that:
Minimize the potential for the growth of microorganisms; and
Prevent adulteration;
Foods that require temperature control for safety are maintained at the temperature:
38°F or less for foods with a non-proteolytic Clostridium botulinum potential hazard;
40°F or less;
45°F or less for molluscan shellfish or shell eggs;
135°F or higher; or
As otherwise approved by the Department;
Food that relies principally on the control of aw for preventing the growth of undesirable microorganisms shall be processed to and maintained at a safe moisture level;
Food that relies principally on the control of pH for preventing the growth of undesirable microorganisms shall be monitored and maintained at a pH of 4.6 or below;
Adequate measures are taken to protect against the inclusion of metal or other extraneous material in food;
Frozen food remains frozen when stored or removed from refrigeration in order to be segregated, organized, or moved;
Frozen foods are thawed in a manner that prevents contamination;
Any food, raw material, or ingredient that is adulterated is not offered to human beings and is:
Rejected upon receipt;
Treated or processed to eliminate the contamination;
Destroyed in a manner that protects against the contamination and allergen cross-contact of other food;
Stored only in a designated area that is:
Separated from all other food and food process operations; and
Conspicuously marked with the intended disposition;
Reconditioned using a method that is safe and effective;
Reexamined following reconditioning and subsequently found not to be adulterated;
Not mixed with another lot of food that is not adulterated; and
If detained by the Department:
Reconditioned; or
Destroyed in a manner approved by the Department;
A facility that only stores unexposed packaged foods that require time and temperature control to significantly minimize or prevent pathogens:
Establishes and implements temperature controls that significantly minimize or prevent the growth of, or toxin production by, pathogens;
Monitors the temperature controls with adequate frequency;
Takes appropriate corrective actions if there is a loss of temperature control that may impact the safety of the food;

Establishes and maintains affirmative or exception records that document implementation of temperature controls, calibration, or accuracy checks of temperature monitoring and recording devices, and corrective actions;
Reviews records of monitoring and corrective actions taken to correct a problem with the control of temperature within:
7 working days after the records are created; or
A reasonable time frame; and
Reviews records of calibration or accuracy checks within a reasonable time frame after the records are created;
Written standard operating procedures are:
Available to employees in a format they understand;
Implemented; and
Reflective of current manufacturing procedures;
When the Department requires a scheduled process, the scheduled process is:
Established by a process authority;
Used to manufacture the target food;
Not changed without approval of the process authority;
Documented by:
Production records; and
Process deviation records; and
Verified by:
Production records review;
Equipment calibration; or
Laboratory testing;
Records that document compliance with this regulation are maintained in accordance with Regulation .06 of this chapter;
Human food by-products for use or distribution as animal food without additional manufacturing or processing are:
Accurately identified when stored;
Stored under conditions that protect against contamination; and
Labeled or accompanied by a label identifying the by-product by the common or usual name when distributed;

Finished product testing for chemicals, microbes, or extraneous materials is conducted when necessary to identify failures to protect ready to eat food from contamination or allergen cross-contact; and
Environmental testing for chemicals or microbes is conducted when necessary to identify failures to protect ready to eat food from contamination or allergen cross-contact.
The food processing plant and grounds around a food processing plant are:
Maintained free of attractants, breeding places, or harborage for pests and insects, including:
Unused equipment;
Debris;
Litter;
Waste; or
High weeds or grass; and
Adequately drained to promote sanitation and prevent breeding places for pests and insects;
The design and construction of the plant facilitates maintenance and sanitary operations for food processing and:
Is suitable in size;
Affords protection against the weather; and
Minimizes the potential for contamination and allergen cross-contact by providing:
Adequate space for the placement of:
Equipment;
Utensils; and
Materials storage; and
Effective designing the flow of food through the plant;

Except as provided for in Regulation .15 of this chapter, a room or area in which food is processed or stored or in which utensils, equipment, or food-packaging materials are cleaned, sanitized, or stored:
Is separated from other rooms or areas in the plant to preclude allergen cross-contact and contamination by:
A distance that precludes allergen cross-contact and contamination; or
Tight fitting:
Walls;
Ceilings; and
Self-closing doors;
Is, if not refrigerated, mechanically ventilated using exhaust and supply fans to ensure:
Filtered air is supplied to provide a positive air pressure in the room;
Condensation and grease do not accumulate on room surfaces and equipment; and
Removal of excessive:
Grease vapors;
Steam;
Heat; and
Odors;
Has a floor, walls, and ceiling that are:
Smooth;
Washable;
Easily cleanable; and
Impervious to water;
Has only the exposed overhead pipes, ducts, conduits, evaporators, and other structures that are needed for proper processing, which are installed so that food is protected against leakage;
Has floor-wall junctures that are:
Coved; and
Impervious to water;
Has aisles or working spaces between equipment and walls that:
Are unobstructed;
Of adequate width to permit employees to perform their duties; and
Protect against the contamination of food, food-contact surfaces, or food-packaging materials by clothing or personal contact;
Provides adequate lighting in all areas that:
Uses shatter-resistant light bulbs, fixtures, skylights, or other light sources if suspended over exposed food, food-contact surfaces, or food-packaging materials in any step of preparation; or
Otherwise protects against food contamination in case of glass breakage; and
Has well-maintained, sealed walls, floors, and ceilings to prevent entry or harborage areas for pests;

Except as provided for in Regulation .15 of this chapter, an area is designated for employees to eat, drink, and securely store personal items which is separate from areas designated for the cleaning, sanitation, or storage of:
Utensils;
Equipment; or
Food-packaging materials;
The food processing plant is completely separated by solid, impervious floors, walls, and ceilings with no connecting openings from areas used as living quarters; and
Plans provided for review to the Department of the plant, facilities, and grounds design and construction that are not provided for in this regulation:
Provide for adequate food safety, food protection, and sanitation; and
Are equivalent to regulatory and industry standards.
Except as provided in §§B and M of this regulation, equipment and utensils meet one or more of the following sanitation design standards:
National Sanitation Foundation (NSF);
The ETL SEMKO division of Intertek Group PLC (Intertek ETL SEMKO);
Canadian Standards Association (CSA);
Underwriters Laboratories (UL);
Bakery Industry Sanitation Standards Committee;
National Automatic Merchandising Association;
International Association of Food Protection;
American Society of Mechanical Engineers;
U.S. Department of Agriculture; or
Another applicable published standard acceptable to the Department;
When design standards conflict with State laws, codes, or regulations, the State laws, codes, or regulations are followed;
Food processing equipment and utensils are:
Designed and constructed to allow for adequate cleaning and sanitizing;
Installed in a way to facilitate cleaning, sanitizing, and maintenance of the equipment and the surrounding areas, including equipment that does not come in contact with food;
Designed and constructed to prevent contamination and allergen cross-contact; and
Maintained in:
Proper working condition; and
A manner that protects against contamination and allergen cross-contact;
Each freezer and cold storage unit used to store and transport food capable of supporting growth of microorganisms:
Maintains temperatures that ensure food safety and protect against spoilage;
Is fitted with an indicating thermometer, temperature-measuring device, or temperature-recording device that is:
Calibrated to be accurate to within plus or minus 2°F; and
Placed in a conspicuous location to show the temperature accurately within the unit;
All food-contact surfaces are designed, constructed, and maintained to be:
Smooth;
Easily cleanable;
Durable;
Non-absorbent;
Constructed of food grade material where applicable;
Corrosion resistant;
Made of nontoxic material that does not impart toxic or deleterious matter to the food;
Inert to food and do not migrate into or adulterate food; and
Smoothly bonded at the seams and maintained to minimize accumulation of:
Food particles;
Dirt; and
Organic matter;
Food-packaging material:
Is food grade;
Is safe;
Is able to maintain food safety and integrity;
Is appropriate for the food item and the intended use;
Is not reused if intended for single-service;
Meets the labeling requirements in Regulation .13B(2) of this chapter;
Does not migrate to or have the potential to be absorbed by food; and
Complies with the requirements of the U.S. Food and Drug Administration in 21 CFR Parts 174—178 for indirect food additives;

Instruments and controls required for measuring, regulating, or recording temperatures, pH, acidity, water activity, or other conditions that control or prevent the growth of undesirable microorganisms in food are accurate and adequate in number for their designated uses;
Thermometers used to monitor required temperatures are calibrated or checked for accuracy annually using an approved method;
Compressed air or other gasses mechanically used to clean food-contact surfaces or equipment are treated in such a way that food is not contaminated with unlawful indirect food additives;
Non-food-contact equipment is:
Smooth;
Easily cleanable;
Durable; and
Non-absorbent;
The food storage area of a transportation vehicle is maintained in:
Good repair;
Working condition; and
A manner that protects against contamination of food;
Containers, equipment, and vehicles used to convey or hold human food by-products for use as animal food are designed and constructed of appropriate material to protect against contamination; and
Equipment submitted to the approving authority for review that meets the provisions of §§C—E of this regulation but fails to comply with §A of this regulation is:
Not harmful to public health; and
Consistent with industry standards and practice.
The water supply is adequate for the operations intended and is:
From an approved potable source;
At an adequate temperature;
Under adequate pressure; and
Protected against backflow;
All plumbing is of adequate size and is designed, installed, and maintained to:
Carry adequate quantities of water to required locations throughout the plant;
Convey sewage and liquid waste from the plant;
Prevent contamination of:
Food;
Water supplies;
Equipment;
Utensils; and
Food-packaging materials;
Ensure sanitary conditions;
Prevent backflow from, or cross-connection between, piping systems that carry wastewater and potable water; and
Be in compliance with State and local codes;
Adequate floor drainage is provided in all areas where:
Floors are subject to water accumulation during cleaning; or
Normal operations release or discharge water or other liquid waste on the floor;
Floors are sloped to floor drains to prevent water accumulation and ponding;
Sewage and wastewater is discharged:
In compliance with applicable laws and regulations;
Into a sewage disposal system that meets all applicable State and local codes; or
Through other acceptable means approved by the Department;
Toilet facilities:
Are readily accessible and adequate in number for employee use;
Are kept clean and are not a potential source of contamination of:
Food;
Food-contact surfaces; and
Food-packaging materials; and
Are provided with:
Signage that instructs individuals to wash their hands before returning to work;

Mechanical air exhaust and intake of an equal amount of makeup air at the rate of 2 cubic feet per minute of air for each square foot of floor area or a screened window that allows the adequate exchange of outside air;
Floors, walls, and a ceiling that are:
Smooth;
Washable;
Easily cleanable; and
Impervious to water;
Floor-wall junctures that are sealed to be impervious to water;
Adequate lighting; and
Hand washing facilities as specified in §G of this regulation;
Hand washing facilities:
Are provided that are adequate in number and conveniently located in areas where food is processed or equipment or utensils are washed and sanitized; and
Are supplied with:
Soap;
Warm water of sufficient volume, under pressure for effective hand washing;
Paper towels or warm air hand drying device;
A conveniently located trash receptacle; and
Hand sanitizer, if necessary to protect against contamination; and
Solid waste:
Is handled and disposed of using waste containers that are:
Adequate in number and size to maintain sanitary conditions;
Conveniently located where waste is generated;
Easily cleanable;
Leak proof; and
Emptied and cleaned at a frequency that maintains sanitary conditions; and
Is handled, stored, and disposed of in a manner that:
Minimizes the development of odors;
Minimizes the potential for becoming an attractant or harborage for pests;
Meets all applicable State and local codes; and
Protects against contamination of:
Food;
Food-contact surfaces;
Food-packaging materials;
Water supplies; and
Plant and grounds.
In accordance with Health-General Article, §21-212, Annotated Code of Maryland, a federal rule that exempts a food from label requirements is effective automatically in the State.
The person-in-charge shall ensure that:
Except as provided in §A of this regulation, food labeling meets the requirements in 21 CFR Part 101;
Except as provided in §A of this regulation, the following information is provided on a label of food in packaged form:
Common or usual name of the food;
Statement of ingredients that gives the common or usual names of the ingredients in descending order of prominence with sub-ingredients listed;
Name and address of the manufacturer or distributor with:
The full street address including the zip code of the manufacturer or distributor if the address is not listed on a website, current city directory, or telephone directory; or
A minimum of the town and zip code if the manufacturer or distributor is listed on a website, current city directory, or telephone directory;
Net quantity in terms of:
Weight in U.S. Customary units and equivalent metric units;
Fluid measure in U.S. Customary units and equivalent metric units;
Numerical count; or
Combination of numerical count and weight;
If a food coloring has been added, the food coloring in the statement of ingredients;
If a chemical preservative has been added, a label declaration stating:
The common or usual name of the ingredient; and
A separate description of its function such as “preservative” or “mold inhibitor”;
Major food allergens in accordance with 21 U.S.C. §343(w);
For a food that requires refrigeration for safety, the words “keep refrigerated” or equivalent;
For a food that requires refrigeration for safety after the food’s packaging is opened, the words “refrigerate after opening” or equivalent;
For a food that is frozen for safety or quality, the words “keep frozen” or equivalent;
A “use by date” if the package contains a food whose safety is assured only until the date specified on the label;
For a food that is frozen during processing or after processing and then thawed before being offered for human consumption, the words “previously frozen, should not refreeze”; and

The exact words “WARNING: This product has not been pasteurized and, therefore, may contain harmful bacteria that can cause serious illness in children, the elderly, and persons with weakened immune systems.” for a juice product that has not been processed in accordance with COMAR 10.15.12;
A food label and the labeling information in §B(1) of this regulation are:
Durable;
Conspicuous;
Legible;
Able to remain on a container for the shelf life of the food; and
Placed on the food container by:
Imprinting;
Embossing;
Lithography;
Ink jetting; or
Another method set forth in 21 CFR Parts 100 and 101 or in conformance with §B(2) of this regulation;
The information required in §B(2) of this regulation is located on the principal display panel;

If the food is not manufactured by the business whose name appears on the label, the business name is qualified by a phrase that reveals the connection the business has with the food, such as “Manufactured for” or “Distributed by”;

If the address given on the label is not the place where the food was actually manufactured, packaged, or distributed, it is the address of the principal place of business of the manufacturer or distributor given on the label;
A food’s labeling or packaging is not false or misleading in any way; and
A food that has been frozen or thermally processed is not labeled “fresh”.
The person-in-charge may forego:
Declaring on the label the common or usual name of each ingredient for incidental additives that:
Have no technical or functional effect in the food; and
Are not required by a federal rule to be declared; and

Complying with the requirements in §B(2)(a)—(f) and (j) of this regulation for a shipment of food that, in accordance with the practice of trade, is processed, labeled, or repacked in substantial quantity at an establishment other than where originally processed or packed if:
The person who introduced the shipment of food into interstate commerce is the operator of the establishment where the food is to be processed, labeled, or repacked; or
The shipment or delivery to the establishment is made under a written agreement as set forth in 21 CFR §101.100(d).
The person-in-charge shall ensure that plans and specifications are submitted to the Department:
Before:
A food processing plant is:
Constructed;
Remodeled; or
Materially altered;
An existing building or structure is converted or remodeled for use as a food processing plant;
A food or process is added or significantly modified; or
A new scheduled process or shelf life study is used; and
That include the following information, as applicable:
A scale drawing in horizontal view that identifies the:
Layout and arrangement of work areas;
Location of food equipment including exhaust ventilation hoods; and
Location of plumbing and plumbing fixtures such as water lines, sewer lines, hand sinks, toilets, utility sinks, utensil washing sinks, floor drains, floor sinks, and hose stations;
Specifications for the:
Construction materials for the building and interior finishes;
Disposal of sewage;
Provision of potable water;
Exclusion and control of pests;
Ventilation of the plant and individual areas within the plant;
Methods and facilities for waste storage and disposal; and
Lighting;
A complete list of specifications for the proposed equipment;
A written description of the foods to be processed, stored, or distributed;
Written standard operating procedures for:
Processing foods named in §A(2)(d) of this regulation;
Employee health and personal hygiene; and
Plant sanitation;
When required by Regulation .02, .07, .10, or .12 of this chapter, a HACCP plan;
When required by the Department, a scheduled process or shelf life study, performed by a process authority;
When required by the Department, a laboratory analysis, performed by a laboratory with a current accreditation to the ISO/IEC 17025;
A hazard analysis and food safety plan as required by Regulation .08B and C of this chapter; and
Any other information that may be required by the Department to ascertain compliance of the plans and specifications with all applicable federal, State and local laws, regulations, and ordinances.

The person-in-charge may not construct a new food processing plant, remodel an existing food processing plant, or manufacture a food using a new or modified process before receiving written approval of the plans and specifications from the Department.
The Department shall:
Review the plans and specifications to ensure compliance with the applicable regulations;
Inform in writing the individual who submitted the plans and specifications:
Of additional information that may be required; and
Following the review, whether the plans and specifications are approved or denied; and

If the plans are denied, provide the individual in writing who submitted the plans and specifications with information on how to appeal the decision, as set forth in State Government Article, Title 10, Subtitle 2, Annotated Code of Maryland.
The person-in-charge shall ensure that before a new or remodeled food processing plant is operated:
The Department schedules and completes an inspection;
The Department issues written approval for the use of the new or remodeled plant; and
For a new plant, a food processing license is obtained.
The Department shall:
Review the plans and specifications to ensure compliance with the applicable regulations;
Conduct a priority assessment of the facility based on the information obtained pursuant to §A(2)(d) and (e) of this regulation; and
Classify a food processing plant as a:
High priority facility, if the food processing plant manufactures food:
Using specialized processes that require a scheduled process or a HACCP Plan;
Using ingredients that require temperature control for safety; or
That is temperature controlled for safety;
Moderate priority facility, if the food processing plant:
Manufactures food using ingredients that do not require temperature control for safety;
Manufactures food that is not temperature controlled for safety; or
Is a food warehouse that stores and distributes food that requires temperature control for safety; or
Low priority facility, if the food processing plant is a food warehouse that stores food or ingredients that do not require temperature control for safety.

The Department may allow the use of equipment that meets the requirements of Regulation .10C—E of this chapter but fails to comply with Regulation .10A of this chapter if a review indicates the equipment and its use are:
Not harmful to public health; and
Consistent with industry standards and practices.

The Department may accept plant, facilities, and grounds design and construction other than those that are provided for in Regulation .09 of this chapter based on a review that shows the alternative plant, facilities, and grounds design:
Provides for adequate food safety, food protection, and sanitation; and
Is equivalent to regulatory and industry standards.

The Department may issue a food processing plant license to an individual who owns, leases, rents, or resides on a farm to process food in a home or domestic kitchen, located on the individual’s farm, as set forth in this regulation.
While operating with a license issued in accordance with §A of this regulation, the person-in-charge shall:
Comply with this chapter except for:
Regulation .09C(2)(a), D, and E; and
Regulation .12D, F(3), and G(1);
Limit processed food production to:
An amount of food that can safely be produced in the domestic kitchen as evidenced by:
Sanitation;
Process; and
Cross-contamination control; and
$50,000 or less of sales other than foods processed under §§E and F of this regulation;
Process commercially only during times when the kitchen is not being used for domestic purposes;
Clean and sanitize all food-contact surfaces, equipment, and utensils, immediately before and after processing commercially;
While processing commercially:
Use only building areas, equipment, and utensils that the Department has reviewed or inspected and approved; and
Remove all animals and individuals not involved in food processing from the kitchen; and
Store ingredients for commercial manufacturing and finished manufactured food in a separate area from foods used domestically.
Except as provided in §§E and F of this regulation, an individual licensed in accordance with this regulation may manufacture and process only:
Baked cakes, muffins, or cookies with a water activity of .85 or less;
Fruit pies with an equilibrated pH of 4.6 or less;
Canned acid foods with an equilibrated pH of 4.6 or less;
Herbs in vinegar with an equilibrated pH of 4.6 or less;
Honey and herb mixtures;
Dried fruits and vegetables; and
Acidified foods.
An individual licensed in accordance with this regulation may not process:
Low-acid canned foods;
Cured or fermented foods;
Except as provided in §E(6) of this regulation, seafood;
Apple cider or other juices;
Grade A milk product or manufactured grade milk product as defined in Health-General Article, §21-401, Annotated Code of Maryland; and
A frozen dessert as defined in Health-General Article, §21-801(b), Annotated Code of Maryland.
An individual licensed in accordance with this regulation may:
Weigh, label, and sell raw meat and poultry that is under the jurisdiction of the United States Department of Agriculture;
Distribute raw meat or poultry that is under the jurisdiction of the United States Department of Agriculture;
Weigh, package, label, and sell raw meat and poultry that is inspected by the Maryland Department of Agriculture in accordance with Regulation .20 of this chapter;
Distribute raw meat or poultry that is inspected by the Maryland Department of Agriculture in accordance with Regulation .20 of this chapter;
Process only animals that were:
Commercially raised, fed, or managed on the farm; and
Slaughtered and processed in accordance with Regulation .17 of this chapter;
While operating a fish farm, clean, weigh, package, label, and sell, or distribute, raw finfish from the farm that are not associated with histamine intoxication; and
Use shared equipment and utensils for both domestic and commercial uses provided that the equipment and utensils are:
Designed and constructed as set forth in Regulation .10 of this chapter; and
Cleaned and sanitized as set forth in Regulation .11 of this chapter.
An individual licensed in accordance with this regulation may weigh, label, store, and distribute cheese that:
Is made on a licensed out-of-State dairy facility using only the raw milk produced by the herd on the dairy farm licensed by the Department; and
Meets the definition and standards of a hard cheese, as set forth in section 21 CFR §133.150.
When a farm ceases to be a farm, a food processing license issued in accordance with this regulation becomes void.

In the absence of a license issued in accordance with COMAR 10.15.03, a license issued in accordance with this regulation shall provide for the sale on the farm of food processed on the farm by the licensee.
Except as provided in Regulation .17 of this chapter, a person may not process food for human consumption on a farm without the license required in Regulation .18A of this chapter.

The Department may issue a food processing plant license to operate a producer mobile farmer’s market unit to transport for sale at a farmer’s market, public festival, or public event, TCS food products:
Produced or stored on the farm by the licensee under an on-farm home processing plant license;
Produced or stored on the farm by the licensee, as authorized by the Department in regulation; or
That have been inspected, licensed, or certified for food safety by the Maryland Department of Agriculture.
The person-in-charge shall ensure that the producer mobile farmer’s market unit:
Complies with Regulations .07G, N, and O and .10D, H, and K of this chapter; and
Displays the license on the unit during operation.
A local health department shall:
Enforce §B of this regulation;
Levy fines as established in local law, ordinance, or regulation;
Notify the Department of any violations occurring in the county; and
Accept a valid producer mobile farmer’s market unit license to sell products authorized for sale under the license without requiring separate licenses or permits.
In order to operate a food processing plant, a person shall obtain a food processing license pursuant to the provisions of:
Health-General Article, §§21-211 and 21-305, Annotated Code of Maryland; and
This chapter.
The Department shall specify on the food processing license what foods or food types the licensee is authorized to process.
The Department shall deny an application for a license if the applicant:
Does not meet the requirements of:
Health-General Article, §21-211, or Title 21, Subtitle 3, Annotated Code of Maryland; or
A regulation promulgated under Health-General Article, §21-211, or Title 21, Subtitle 3, Annotated Code of Maryland; or
Fraudulently or deceptively attempts to obtain a license.
The Department may suspend or revoke a license if the licensee:
Violates or fails to meet the requirements of §C of this regulation; or
Fraudulently or deceptively obtains a license.
The Department may deny an application for a food processing plant license and may suspend or revoke a license pursuant to the provisions of:
Health-General Article, §§21-211, 21-311, and 21-314—21-317, Annotated Code of Maryland; and
State Government Article, §10-226, Annotated Code of Maryland.
The person-in-charge shall ensure that:
Food is not processed without the license required by Health-General Article, §21-305, Annotated Code of Maryland;
The required food processing license is conspicuously posted in the plant; and
The processing operations in the plant are limited to the food type or types specified on the license pursuant to §B of this regulation.
Except as provided in §H of this regulation, a license may not be transferred from one person to another person or from one food processing plant to another.
On the death of a licensee, the approving authority may transfer a food processing plant license if:
An application is filed in accordance with Health-General Article, §21-306, Annotated Code of Maryland; and
Written evidence establishes that the applicant’s relationship with the deceased was as a:
Spouse of the deceased licensee;
Blood relative to the first degree of consanguinity; or
Current officer or surviving partner in the business operating the food processing plant.
The person-in-charge shall permit a representative of the Department to:
Enter a food processing plant at a reasonable time for the purpose of making inspections to determine compliance with this chapter; and
Examine the records of the facility that pertain to information regarding food and supplies:
Purchased;
Received;
Manufactured;
Sold; or
Distributed.
The person-in-charge shall inform the Department of a food ingredient or a recipe that the person-in-charge considers a trade secret, except as provided in §C of this regulation.
The person-in-charge shall provide information to the Department regarding a food ingredient or recipe that the person-in-charge considers a trade secret if:
An immediate and substantial danger to public health exists involving the food ingredient or recipe; or
The Department determines that the information about the food ingredient or recipe is necessary to conduct a foodborne disease investigation.
The person-in-charge shall ensure that:
Compliance with this chapter is continuous;
Violations are corrected within the time for correction given by the Department;
When a violation of a critical item exists:
The violation is corrected immediately;
Food processing affected by the critical item violation ceases; or
The food processing plant is closed immediately; and
For a food processing plant that operates seasonally or intermittently, inspection and regulation by the Department is facilitated by notifying the Department of:
The dates and times of operation; or
Information necessary to ensure that the Department has the opportunity to inspect the food processing plant during plant operation.
The Department shall maintain the confidentiality of trade secret information in accordance with General Provisions Article, §4-335, and Health-General Article, §21-259, Annotated Code of Maryland.
When an inspection of a food processing plant is made, the Department shall:
Complete an inspection report that identifies the:
Conditions found that violate the provisions of this chapter; and
Critical item violations, noted separately from all other violations;
Provide a copy of the inspection report to the person-in-charge of the plant; and

Make the completed inspection report form available for public disclosure in accordance with General Provisions Article, §§4-101—4-104, 4-201—4-206, 4-301—4-362, and 4-501—4-503, Annotated Code of Maryland.
The Department shall ensure that a food processing plant is inspected:
As determined by the Department or by statute for the enforcement of this chapter;
At a minimum of the frequency required by COMAR 10.15.07.01 for any shellfish:
Shucker-packer; or
Repacker;
At a minimum of two times per year for any shellfish:
Shipper; or
Reshipper;
At another frequency for shellfish required by COMAR 10.15.07.01; or
When a:
High priority plant, at a minimum of once per 12 months;
Moderate priority plant, at a minimum of once per 24 months; and
Low priority plant, at a minimum of once every 36 months.

section.heading: Foodborne Disease Investigation and Control.
section.text: The approving authority shall ensure that:

para.text: When there is reasonable cause to suspect foodborne disease transmission or an outbreak from a food processed or distributed by a food processing plant, an inspection of the plant is conducted to:
Identify:
Potential points of food contamination in the facility;
Whether employee illness may have contributed; and
Whether a contaminated ingredient was used to process a food; and
Determine if affected food has been distributed into commerce; and
The appropriate follow-up action is taken, which may include immediate:
Closing of the food processing plant, or a portion of the plant that is used to process the implicated product; or

Exclusion of a suspect employee from all food handling positions within the plant until medical and epidemiological evidence shows that the likelihood of further foodborne disease transmission is low in accordance with COMAR 10.06.01.
