para.text: An individual applying for a license or certificate of eligibility shall:
Submit the appropriate application in writing on a form provided by the Board;
Pay the application fee established by COMAR 10.60.06;
Have official transcripts of all baccalaureate and post-baccalaureate studies submitted in accordance with §B of this regulation; and
Have verification of previous experience, if applicable, submitted in accordance with §C of this regulation.
Transcripts.
Official transcripts of all baccalaureate and post-baccalaureate studies shall be submitted directly to the Board from the appropriate educational institutions.
If official transcripts are not available, the Board may accept other evidence certifying successful completion of course work considered equivalent by the Board.
A graduate of a college or university that is not an accredited educational institution shall provide written documentation from an evaluation service, or other source acceptable to the Board, which:
States that the institution’s program of study is substantially equivalent to that of accredited educational institutions; and
Shows that the course work completed by the applicant satisfies the requirements of COMAR 10.60.01.03B.

An applicant for a license who claims experience as an environmental health specialist shall provide to the Board independent written verification from the applicant’s employer describing the nature and duration of the applicant’s experience.
The Board shall notify an applicant in writing that:
The applicant qualifies for a license under COMAR 10.60.01.03 or .04;
The applicant qualifies for:
Examination under COMAR 10.60.01.03; or
A certificate of eligibility under COMAR 10.60.02.05;
The applicant does not qualify to receive a license or a certificate of eligibility, or to take the examination, for one or more of the reasons set forth in §C of this regulation; or
The application is incomplete, the reasons the application is incomplete, and that the application will be invalid in 1 year.
Payment of License Fee.
Following notification of license approval, the applicant shall pay to the Board the licensing fee established in COMAR 10.60.06.
The license may not be issued until the fee is paid to the Board.
Denial of an Application.
The Board shall deny an application if the Board determines that the applicant:
Has failed to demonstrate that the applicant qualifies for licensure, examination, or issuance of a certificate in accordance with §A(1) or (2) of this regulation; or
Has committed any act which, under Health Occupations Article, §21-312, Annotated Code of Maryland, would subject the licensee to disciplinary action by the Board.
If the Board denies an application, the Board shall:
Notify the applicant by first-class mail and electronic means of the reasons for denial;
Advise the applicant of the procedures for reconsideration under §D of this regulation if the application was denied under §C(1)(a) of this regulation; and
Follow the procedures set forth in COMAR 10.60.04 if the application was denied under §C(1)(b) of this regulation.
Reconsideration.

If the Board denies an application for licensure under Regulation .03C(1)(a) of this chapter, or denies an application to renew a license under Regulation .06 of this chapter, the applicant may request reconsideration of the denial by submitting new or additional information to the Board.
Requests for reconsideration under §D(1) of this regulation shall be based on one or more of the following grounds:
Clerical errors in the minutes, decisions, or other parts of the record related to the denial;
Mistake of fact or law by the Board;
Irregularity in the administrative proceedings related to, or in the consideration of, the application;
Newly discovered or additional evidence that the applicant could not have discovered by due diligence in time to be considered as part of the initial denial.
Requests for reconsideration shall be submitted to the Board in writing by certified mail within 30 days of receipt of the denial under §C of this regulation.
The Board shall:
Authorize a recognized examination agency to administer the examination on behalf of the Board; or
Administer an examination prepared by a recognized examination agency.
The examination shall be:
Standardized and prepared by a recognized examination agency; and
Held at least once a year.
The Board shall provide the:
List of eligible applicants and their eligibility expiration date to an authorized examination agency;
For applicants who have satisfied education and experience requirements set forth under COMAR 10.60.01.03, notice of eligibility to sit for the examination;
Examination information for eligible applicants on the Board’s website;
Results of the examination to the applicant; and
For applicants who receive a passing score, instructions on securing a license.
The notice of eligibility to an applicant shall include the:
Date the:
Applicant is eligible to sit for the examination; and
Eligibility to sit for the examination expires; and
Procedure to:
Register to sit for the examination;
Pay the fee for examination; and
Retake the examination.
The authorized examination agency shall:
Collect the examination fee from the applicant; and
Provide examination results to the Board.
Passing Score. The passing score for the examination shall be determined by the recognized examination agency.
An applicant who has not previously taken the written examination is permitted to sit for an examination if the applicant has:
Received a notice of eligibility from the Board; and
Paid an examination fee as established by COMAR 10.60.06.
An applicant who fails the examination may retake the examination if the applicant:
Submits an application on a form required by the Board; and
Pays any applicable examination fees.
An applicant, who receives an in-training certificate after January 1, 2022, may not sit for the examination after their in-training certificate expires.
The Board may not accept examination results unless all eligibility requirements set forth in this regulation are met.
The Board may waive any examination requirement under this regulation if the Board considers the applicant to be recognized as outstanding in the field of environmental health.
To be recognized as outstanding in the field of environmental health by the Board, an applicant shall:
Meet the criteria set forth in COMAR 10.60.01.03 and 10.60.02.01 for an environmental health specialist-in-training;
Be considered a subject matter expert by the Board in one or more of the following areas:
The manufacture, preparation, handling, distribution, or sale of food and milk;
Water supply and treatment;
Wastewater treatment and disposal;
Solid waste management and disposal;
Vector control;
Insect and rodent control;
Air quality;
Noise control;
Product safety;
Recreational sanitation; or
Institutional and residential sanitation;
Demonstrate at least one of the following career pathways with a minimum of 15 years of progressive responsibilities with:

Technical knowledge and experience, including obtaining a master’s or doctoral degree in an environmental or public health-related area, wherein the time devoted to technical scientific research may be applied towards the minimum time criteria as follows:
If obtaining a master’s degree, 1 year; or
If obtaining a doctoral degree, 2 years;
A managerial hierarchy similar to that of an environmental health specialist, such as:
Health specialist in training;
Licensed environmental health specialist;
Supervisor;
Program manager; or
Director; or
A combination of §L(3)(a) or (b) of this regulation; and
Demonstrate and document involvement in an area listed in §L(2) of this regulation, in at least one of the following activities:
Research;
Has been published in peer review publications;
Has given court testimony or served as an expert witness qualified by a court system;
Has teaching experience; or
Where applicable, received a professional license through a Maryland or other recognized licensure body in the applicant’s field.
Certificate of Eligibility for Obtaining Employment.
The Board shall issue a certificate of eligibility for obtaining employment to an applicant who:
Meets the educational requirements set forth in COMAR 10.60.01.03;
Has submitted an application in accordance with Regulation .01 of this chapter;
Is not currently practicing as an environmental health specialist in Maryland; and
Has not previously completed an environmental health specialist-in-training program under an environmental health specialist-in-training certificate issued by the Board.
The certificate of eligibility for obtaining employment shall expire 12 months after the issuance date and may be renewed at 12-month increments if the certificate holder:
Submits a request for renewal on a form provided by the Board; and
Forwards the form to the Board together with the renewal fee established by COMAR 10.60.06.
Environmental Health Specialist-In-Training Certificates.

The Board shall issue an environmental health specialist-in-training certificate to an applicant who has been employed to practice as an environmental health specialist under a certificate of eligibility for obtaining employment issued by the Board if the applicant:
Has returned a completed certificate of eligibility for obtaining employment to the Board; and
Is participating in an environmental health specialist-in-training program.

The environmental health specialist-in-training certificate shall expire 36 months after its effective date unless the expiration date has been extended in writing by the Board in accordance with §B(4) or (6) of this regulation.
The Board may not renew an environmental health specialist-in-training certificate for which the expiration date has been extended.

Upon a written request from the holder of an environmental health specialist-in-training certificate, the Board may extend an environmental health specialist-in-training certificate for up to 6 months due to physical incapacitation of the environmental health specialist-in-training or for other reasons acceptable to the Board.

The Board may place the environmental health specialist-in-training certificate on inactive status due to reasons acceptable to the Board upon a written request from the holder of an environmental health specialist-in-training certificate.

The Board may reactivate the environmental health specialist-in-training certificate within the original 36 month period with an expiration date that reflects the balance of remaining time for training:
Upon a written request from an individual whose environmental health specialist-in-training certificate is inactive; and
Along with a letter of support from a sponsor.

If the holder of an environmental health specialist-in-training certificate is a temporary employee as defined in COMAR 10.60.01.01, the Board, upon written request from the holder of the environmental health specialist-in-training certificate and upon receipt of the renewal fee as required by COMAR 10.60.06, may renew a valid certificate for a period of 24 months.
If a temporary employee is hired as or otherwise converted to a permanent employee:
The employee shall submit the employee’s current environmental health specialist-in-training certificate to the Board within 30 days;
Upon receipt of the certificate referenced in §D(6)(a) of this regulation, the Board shall renew a new environmental health specialist-in-training certificate that is valid for 36 months; and
The Board may reduce the required number of months of experience in an environmental health specialist-in-training program.
Expiration. After June 30, 2023, licenses shall expire pursuant to the following schedule:
The license of a licensee with an even-numbered birth year shall expire on June 30 of an even-numbered year; and
The license of a licensee with an odd-numbered birth year shall expire on June 30 of an odd-numbered year
Conditions for License Renewal.
Except as provided in §B(2) and (3) of this regulation, the Board shall renew a license for a 2-year period if the licensee has:
Submitted an application for renewal to the Board before the expiration date of the license;
Paid the renewal fee established by COMAR 10.60.06;
Submitted satisfactory proof to the Board that the licensee has completed at least 20 clock hours of approved training during the license renewal period; and
Not committed any act which, under Health Occupations Article, §21-312, Annotated Code of Maryland, would subject the licensee to disciplinary action by the Board.

For licenses expiring on June 30, 2023 only, the Board shall renew the license of a licensee with an even-numbered birth year for a 1-year period if the licensee meets the requirements set forth under §B(1) of this regulation.
For licenses expiring on June 30, 2024 only, the Board shall renew a license for a 2-year period if the licensee has:
Submitted an application for renewal to the Board before the expiration date of the license;
Paid the renewal fee established by COMAR 10.60.06;
Submitted satisfactory proof to the Board that the licensee has completed at least 10 clock hours of approved training during the 1-year period immediately preceding the license expiration date; and
Not committed any act which, under Health Occupations Article, §21-312, Annotated Code of Maryland, would subject the licensee to disciplinary action by the Board.
The Board may deny the application to renew a license if the applicant has failed to satisfy the requirements of §B of this regulation.
Renewal Notification.
Before the expiration of a license, the Board shall notify the licensee of the need to renew the license.
The failure of a licensee to receive a renewal notice does not:
Relieve the licensee of the obligation to renew the license; and
Affect the expiration of the license.

section.heading: Duplicate License.
section.text: A licensee may obtain a duplicate license to replace a license that has been lost, destroyed, or mutilated if the licensee:

para.text: Makes a written request to the Board that states the reason for requesting a duplicate license; and
Pays to the Board the duplicate license fee established by COMAR 10.60.06.
The Board shall place a licensed environmental health specialist on inactive status for a period not to exceed 4 years if the licensee:
Submits to the Board a written application for inactive status on a form the board requires; and
Pays to the Board the inactive status fee set by the Board.
The Board shall provide to a licensed environmental health specialist who is placed on inactive status written notification of:
The date the license has or will expire;
The date the inactive status became effective;
The date the inactive status expires; and
The consequences of not reactivating the license before the inactive status expires.
Except as provided in Regulation .10 of this chapter, the Board shall reactivate the license of a licensed environmental health specialist who is on inactive status if the licensee:
Applies to the Board for reactivation of the license before the inactive status expires;
Complies with the license renewal requirements that are in effect when the licensee applies for reactivation;
Has completed 20 credit hours of approved continuing education in the past 24 month period; and
Pays to the Board the reactivation fee established by COMAR 10.60.06(7).
An applicant for reactivation of a license shall submit to the Board documentation of completion of approved training as set forth in COMAR 10.60.03.04E.

The Board shall place a licensed environmental health specialist on non-renewed status for a period not to exceed 4 years if the licensed environmental health specialist fails to renew the license for any reason.
The Board shall provide to the licensee who is placed on nonrenewed status written notification of:
The date the license expired;
The date the non-renewed status became effective;
The date the non-renewed status expires; and
The consequences of not reactivating the license before the non-renewed status expires.
Except as provided in Regulation .10 of this chapter, the Board shall reactivate the license of a licensed environmental health specialist who is on non-renewed status if the individual:
Applies to the Board for reactivation of the license before the non-renewed status expires;
Complies with the license renewal requirements that are in effect when the individual applies for reactivation;
Has completed 20 credit hours of approved continuing education in the past 24 month period; and

Pays to the Board the reactivation fee established by COMAR 10.60.06.D. An applicant for reactivation of a license shall submit to the Board documentation of completion of approved training as set forth in COMAR 10.60.03.04E.
An applicant for reactivation of a license shall submit to the Board documentation of completion of approved training as set forth in COMAR 10.60.03.04E.

section.heading: Reactivation.
section.text: Notwithstanding Regulations .08 and .09 of this chapter, the Board shall reactivate the license of a licensed environmental health specialist who was placed on inactive or non-renewed status if the individual:

para.text: Applies to the Board for reactivation after the inactive or non-renewed status expired;
Pays to the Board the reactivation fee established by COMAR 10.60.06;
Provides any documentation required by the Board; and
Passes the examination that is required at time of reactivation.

para.text: An employee wishing to file an appeal must notify the SSOA within 15 calendar days of receiving the notice of the suspension, to request an administrative hearing.
When a suspension is contested, the SSOA will forward the matter to Maryland Office of Administrative Hearings (OAH) to set in for a hearing.
The hearing will be conducted in accordance with Title 28 of the Code of Maryland Regulations (COMAR 28.02.01).
The administrative law judge’s decision is the final order of the MDOT Deputy Secretary of Policy, Planning, and Enterprise Services.

Effective date:

para.text: Lawful Gear.
A person may catch crabs in the tidal waters of Maryland only with the gear authorized in this chapter.
Diving Apparatus. A person may not possess or catch crabs in the tidal waters of Maryland using diving apparatus by itself, or in conjunction with any of the other methods authorized in this chapter.
Gear designated to catch crabs and defined in this chapter, except for a seine, is not considered a net under the definition listed in COMAR 08.02.05.02.
Recreational Gear — Definitions.
The gear defined in this section may be used to catch crabs for recreational purposes.
“Bushel” means a:
Circular container with the following inside dimensions:
18 inches top diameter;
13-1/2 inches bottom diameter; and
12 inches height; or
Rectangular container with the following inside dimensions:
11 inches height;
19½ inches length; and
12½ inches width.
"Collapsible crab trap" means a manually operated, portable device:
Having a flat bottom not more than 20 inches by 15 inches, and not more than four articulated sides; and
Designed so that failure to apply manually exerted tension on the closing mechanism allows the crabs to escape.
"Crab net ring" means a manually operated, portable device that:
Consists of:
Two rings, each of a different diameter, connected by netting, where the larger of the two rings shall be less than or equal to 30 inches in diameter; or
One ring that shall be less than or equal to 30 inches in diameter, connected to netting;
When baited and lowered to the bottom, lies flat on the bottom; and
When pulled to the surface, forms a deep pocket out of the netting.
"Crab pot" means a cube-shaped or rectangular shaped device with openings toward the inside for the entrance of crabs.
"Dip net" means a mesh bag of netting or wire which is suspended from a circular, oval, or a rectangular frame attached to a handle.
"Handline" means an unbuoyed fishing line managed primarily by hand.
"Trotline" means a length of rope or line, buoyed at both ends with one or more anchors, which is baited without hooks or snares at intervals for the purpose of catching crabs.
"Seine" means an encircling type of net which is not more than 50 feet long and 5 feet wide.
Commercial Gear.
In addition to the gear listed in §B(2)—(8) of this regulation, the gear defined in this section may also be used for commercial crab harvesting.
"Bank trap" means an enclosure constructed of wire mesh not more than 4 feet long and not more than 4 feet wide, with a single row of hedging not more than 75 feet long.
“Barrel” means a container which holds not more than 2-1/2 U.S. standard bushels of crabs and does not exceed the following inside dimensions:
20½ inches across the top diameter;
27½ inches height; and
18 inches along the bottom diameter.
"Channel pound" means an enclosure constructed of wire mesh not more than 8 feet long and not more than 4 feet wide, with two rows of hedging, each not longer than 100 feet long.
"Crab scrape" means a scoop or other device which is dragged along the bottom for the purpose of catching crabs.
"Hand scrape" means a single scoop or other device which is:
Dragged along the bottom for the purpose of catching crabs; and
Retrieved by hand without the aid of any mechanical device during any stage of the retrieval.
“Lug” means a rectangular-shaped container that does not exceed the following inside dimensions:
22-7/8 inches in length across the top;
14-7/8 inches in width across the top;
21 inches length across the bottom;
13 inches width across the bottom; and
12-3/8 inches height.
An individual may not set or fish a trotline within 100 feet of another individual’s set trotline, collapsible crab trap, or net ring.
The length of a trotline shall be measured along the bait line from the first bait to the last bait.
In the coastal bays of the Atlantic Ocean and their tidal tributaries:
An individual may not use or possess on board a vessel a trotline or trotlines with a baited portion more than 600 feet in length to catch or attempt to catch crabs for recreational purposes; or

If two or more individuals are on a boat, not more than two trotlines with a baited portion more than 600 feet each may be used or possessed on board a vessel to catch or attempt to catch crabs for recreational purposes.
In the Chesapeake Bay and its tidal tributaries:
Trotline gear may only be used to catch or attempt to catch crabs:
For commercial purposes by an individual licensed in accordance with Natural Resources Article, §4-701, Annotated Code of Maryland; or
For recreational purposes by an individual licensed in accordance with Regulation .09 of this chapter;

An individual licensed to catch crabs for recreational purposes may not use or possess on board a vessel a trotline or trotlines with a baited portion more than 1,200 feet in length to catch or attempt to catch crabs for recreational purposes; and
The trotline gear used from the boat may not exceed 1,200 feet in length for the baited portion:
Regardless of the number of individuals licensed to catch crabs for recreational purposes on a boat; or
If the boat is licensed as a recreational crabbing boat.
Buoy Requirements.
A trotline shall have a three-dimensional buoy of the same color, size, and shape attached to each end.
Buoys that have a spherical shape shall be at least 12 inches in diameter.
Buoys that do not have a spherical shape shall be at least:
12 inches long;
10 inches wide; and
10 inches high.
Buoys shall be marked with the owner’s:
DNR id number, if recreationally crabbing in the Chesapeake Bay or its tidal tributaries;
Name and address, if recreationally crabbing in the Atlantic Ocean, its coastal bays, or their tidal tributaries; or
Commercial license number.
A crab scrape may not:
Have a bar wider than 60 inches;
Have teeth or projections of any kind;
Have a flat plate attached to the scraping bar, which is the bar that touches the bottom;
Have a diver, chain, or other device attached to it or the taking line to hold the scrape to the bottom; and
Exceed 80 pounds in weight, including the bag.
Number of Scrapes Permitted.
A person may not use more than two scrapes in any vessel that is propelled by an engine.
Scrapes may not be affixed to each other so as to form a single fishing unit.
Prohibited Areas. Scrapes are prohibited in the following areas:
St. Mary's River—that portion lying upriver from a line drawn between Chancellor Point and Portobello Point;
Calvert Bay and Smith Creek—that portion north of a line drawn between Kitts Point and Lawson Point;
All submerged lands leased for shellfish cultivation in accordance with Natural Resources Article, Title 4, Subtitle 11A, Annotated Code of Maryland; and

The waters of the Chesapeake Bay and tidal tributaries north of a line extending in a westerly direction from the southern point of the mouth of Punch Island Creek in Dorchester County defined by Lat. 38°25'15.2"N., Long. 76°17'19.7"W. to Cove Point in Calvert County defined by Lat. 38°23'05.4"N., Long. 76°22'52.3"W.

Hand Scrapes. Notwithstanding §C(4) of this regulation, a person may use a single scrape not wider than 48 inches and not heavier than 45 pounds north of the line defined in §C(4) of this regulation in the following areas:

The area of the Chesapeake Bay east of a line drawn from a point at or near Cook Point in Dorchester County defined by Lat. 38°37'41.5"N., Long. 76°17'21.1"W.; then running approximately 193° True to a point at or near Hills Point in Dorchester County defined by Lat. 38°34'19.9"N., Long. 76°18'21.2"W.; and
The waters of Queen Anne's County and Kent County.
A bank trap and channel pound shall meet the following structural requirements:
A row of hedging attached to any bank trap or channel pound may not exceed more than 1/3 the distance across the body of water in which the bank trap or channel pound is placed;

To permit trapped air-breathing animals to survive, each bank trap and channel pound shall be constructed and placed in the water to provide an airspace safety chamber in the top of the trap which shall extend 12 inches above the water at mean high tide, and consist of a cube not less than 12 inches on each side and 12 inches high, or a cylinder not less than 18 inches in diameter and 12 inches high; and
A marker shall be attached to each bank trap and channel pound, which clearly identifies the name and license number of the owner in letters at least 2 inches high.
Areas Where Bank Traps and Channel Pounds May Be Placed.
An individual may place a bank trap or channel pound only in the following tidal waters:

The waters surrounding Eastern Neck Island from Baybush Point along the south and easterly sides of the island to the bridge crossing Eastern Neck Narrows, except within 300 feet of another bank trap or channel pound; and
The tidal waters of Somerset County except within:
300 feet of another bank trap or channel pound; or

500 feet of the point, formed at the intersection of a line from the nearest part of the dwelling to the water and a line along the mean high water mark, of property that contains an occupied dwelling.

In Somerset County, a bank trap or channel pound may not be placed closer than the distance specified in §B(1)(b)(ii) of this regulation from a waterfront residence, unless written permission has been obtained from the owner, tenant, or lessee of the waterfront property. This permission shall include the signature, address, and telephone number of the owner, tenant, or lessee.
If written permission is required, it shall be shown to a Natural Resources Police officer or other law enforcement officer upon request.
An individual may not set more than 35 bank traps or channel pounds in the tidal waters of Somerset County.
Times for Staking Out and Removing Bank Traps or Channel Pounds.
After 8 a.m. on March 15, a licensee may use in each instance a single stake with the licensee's name and license number to stake out one or more sites for bank traps or channel pounds.

Beginning on March 1 of each year, a landowner or lessee may use in each instance a single stake with the landowner's or lessee's name and address to stake out one site in the area riparian to the landowner's or lessee's land where the landowner or lessee may maintain a trap or pound. An individual other than the landowner or lessee may not place or maintain a trap or pound in that area, if the area is staked by a landowner or lessee.
Each bank trap and hedging shall be in place not later than May 1 or the staking of the site is void and may be staked out by another licensee.
An individual shall remove a bank trap or channel pound, including all hedging and stakes, by December 1.
If a bank trap or channel pound is removed before December 1, all hedging and stakes shall be removed 30 days after the trap is removed.
“Cull ring” means a device in a crab pot, for the escapement of undersized crabs, described as a:
Ring with an opening of the established measurement for the inside diameter; or

Square opening cut from the crab pot measuring at least 4-1/2 inches by 4-1/2 inches and covered by a panel of 2-inch by 2-inch mesh so that there are at least four complete 2-inch by 2-inch square meshes.
A crab pot shall meet the following structural requirements:
A standard cube type crab pot may not have sides which are more than 24 inches long;
Rectangular crab pots may not have dimensions which are greater than 12 inches high, 24 inches wide, and 48 inches long in total;
A crab pot shall be constructed of wire having a mesh measuring along its longest axis when the wire is unstretched of not less than:
1-1/2 inches for the purpose of catching hard crabs; or
1 inch for the purpose of catching peeler crabs;

Except for a crab pot constructed with unstretched mesh measuring less than 1-1/2 inches or at least 2 inches on each side, a crab pot set in the Chesapeake Bay or its tidal tributaries shall have two cull rings, one of at least 2-3/16 inches and one of at least 2-5/16 inches inside diameter located in exterior side panels or the top panel of the crab pot; and
A crab pot set for recreational purposes shall have a turtle reduction device which:
Is firmly attached to each entrance or funnel in the lower chamber;
Is constructed of wire or plastic;
Is rectangular in shape; and
Has dimensions which do not exceed 1-3/4 inches high and 4-3/4 inches long.
Times for Setting and Removing Crab Pots.
Crab pots may not be set in State waters before March 31 of each year.
All crab pots shall be removed from the waters of the Chesapeake Bay and its tidal tributaries by December 31 of each year.
All crab pots shall be removed from the waters of the coastal bays of the Atlantic Ocean and their tidal tributaries:
If set for commercial purposes, by November 16 of each year; or
If set for recreational purposes, by December 31 of each year.
General Requirements.
A person may use crab pots to catch crabs for recreational purposes only:
If the person is:
An owner, lessee, or tenant of a private property along the shore; or
A guest of an owner, lessee, or tenant of a private property along the shore;
If using the crab pot in accordance with §§B, C, D, and H of this regulation; and
If crabbing from a property located on the Chesapeake Bay or its tidal tributaries, only if the crab pots have been properly registered with the Department.
Not more than two crab pots set for recreational purposes may be attached to a property or privately owned pier, regardless of the number of owners or lessees of that property.
Notwithstanding §§E and G of this regulation, a crab pot set for recreational purposes shall be:
Set in front of the person's property, within 100 yards of the shore, and:
Attached by a line to the property or a privately owned pier or dock; or
Marked by a buoy or pole and sign; and
Marked with the owner's:
DNR id number, if crabbing in the Chesapeake Bay or its tidal tributaries; or
Name and address, if crabbing in the Atlantic Ocean, its coastal bays, or their tidal tributaries.
Buoys for Commercially Set Crab Pots.
Each pot individually set shall be marked with a buoy that is easily visible on the surface.
Each string of pots shall be marked at each end with a buoy that is easily visible on the surface.

Each buoy shall be clearly marked with the identification number of the licensee in letters at least 2 inches high, and, if the buoy is attached to a string of crab pots, with the number of pots in the string.
The Department may require individual numbered markers supplied by the Department to be attached to every buoy.

While crabbing in the Chesapeake Bay and its tidal tributaries, a person licensed to catch crabs with more than 50 crab pots may not at any time set or fish more than 300 crab pots unless the person is authorized to set or fish 600 or 900 crab pots.
A person commercially licensed to catch crabs may set crab pots in the coastal bays of the Atlantic Ocean and their tidal tributaries subject to the following limitations:
A person licensed to catch crabs with more than 50 pots may not set or fish more than 300 pots; and
Regardless of the number of licensees per boat, not more than 300 pots may be set or fished.
Crabs may not be in the bait box of the crab pot.
Except as specifically allowed, crab pots may not be set in the waters described in §§F—I of this regulation.

Atlantic Coastal Bays. Crab pots may not be set in waters designated as having a speed zone in accordance with COMAR 08.18.18.01, 08.18.18.03, 08.18.18.05, and 08.18.18.06.
Crab pots may not be set in waters that are less than 4 feet deep at mean low tide except as provided below:

In Pocomoke Sound, all the waters shoreward of the Maryland-Virginia state line, starting with the junction with a line running from Bullbegger Point westward to the northeasternmost point of land on Fair Island defined by Lat. 37° 57.837' N, Long. 75° 38.914' W, then following the State line in a westerly direction to State line marker "A" defined by Lat. 37° 54.732' N, Long. 75° 48.065' W, thence northwesterly to Ware Point defined by Lat. 37° 56.348' N, Long. 75° 49.264' W.

Chesapeake Beach — 100 yards north of a line from Fl. G 6 § "3" PA to Fl. G 4 § 4M "1";
Flag Harbor — Within 100 yards of the stone jetty of Flag Harbor;

Patuxent River — 35 yards each side of a line extending northeasterly beginning at a point at or near the mouth of the Patuxent River, defined by Lat. 38°18.86'N., Long. 76°24.61'W.; then running approximately 52° True to a point defined by Lat. 38°19.57'N., Long. 76°23.47'W.; then running approximately 51° True to a point defined by Lat. 38°19.98'N., Long. 76°22.82'W.; then running approximately 52° True to a point defined by Lat. 38°20.47'N., Long. 76°22.03'W.;
St. Clements Bay — St. Patrick Creek — Channel marked by Fl. R 4 § 14 ft. 3M "2" PA westerly to the entrance to St. Patrick Creek R "6";
St. George Island Straits — Channel marked by GPA "3" northeasterly to the bridge between Straits Point and St. George Island;

Honga River — Tar Bay — 50 yards channelward of a line from Fishing Creek Bridge westerly to Fl. R 4 § 16 ft. 4M "8", Fl. 4 § 4M "7", Fl. R 4 § 15 ft. 3M "6", Fl. 4 § 5M "5", Fl. R 4 § 15 ft. 3M "4", Fl. 4 § 16 ft. 5M "3", Fl. R 4 § 14 ft. 3M "2", Fl. G 4 § 14 ft. 6M "1";
Honga River — Middle Hooper Island — 50 yards channelward of a line from Middle Hooper Island Bridge to Fl. G 4 § 15 ft. 3M "1";
Deal Island — 50 yards channelward of a line from Deal Island Harbor to Fl. R 6 § "6", Fl. G 2.5 § 15 ft. 3M "1";
Wenona — 50 yards channelward of a line from Wenona Harbor to Qk. Fl. "6" to Fl. R 4 § "4";
Pocomoke Sound — Broad Creek — 50 yards channelward of a line northerly from Fl. 2.5 § 14 ft. 4M "2", R "4", R "6" into Broad Creek;
Pocomoke River — 50 yards channelward of a line easterly from Fl. 4 § "1", R N "2", C "3", R N "4", C "5";
Smith Island — 50 yards channelward of a line easterly from the entrance to Smith Island to R "8", Fl. G 4 § 14 ft. "3", R "2", Fl. 2.5 § 14 ft. "1";

Isle Of Wight Bay — Eastern Channel, 50 yards channelward of a line southward from day marker "13", C "11", R N "10", G C "9", R N "8", G C "7", R N "6", C "5", C "3", R N "2", C "1", Fl. R 4 § 14 ft. 3M "2", G "1A" to U.S. Route 50 Bridge;
Isle Of Wight Bay — Western Channel, 50 yards channelward of a line southward from Fl. R 2.5 § "14", R N "12", R N "10", R N "8", R N "6", C "1";
Isle Of Wight Bay — 100 feet channelward of a line from Ocean Pines Yacht Club easterly to Fl. R 2 § 6 ft. "4", Fl. G 2 § 6 ft. "3", Fl. 2 § 6 ft. "2";
Chincoteague Bay — 50 yards channelward of a line from Public Landing Harbor easterly to Fl. G 2.5 § 15 ft. 3M "1";
Chincoteague Bay — 50 yards channelward of a line from the entrance to Tanhouse Creek easterly to Fl. R 2.5 § 14 ft. 4 M "2";

Herring Bay — In a channel defined by corner coordinates beginning at the northeast corner at Lat. 38°44'31"N., Long. 76°30'50"W., and then southerly to Lat. 38°44'25"N., Long. 76°30'50"W., and then westerly to Lat. 38°44'22"N., Long. 76°31'47"W., and then northerly to Lat. 38°44'28"N., Long. 76°31'48"W., and then easterly to the point of origin;
Susquehanna Flats — 100 yards either side of line from Junction Buoy "A" Fl. (2+1) 6 § to G "1" Fl. G 2.5 § to R N "2" to Fl. G "3"; and
Susquehanna Flats — 200 yards west of a line from Junction Buoy "A" Fl. (2+1) 6 § to R "2" Fl. R 4 §

Except as provided in §B of this regulation, a person may not possess, transport, or pack a female crab from which the egg pouch or bunion has been removed, or an egg-bearing female crab known as the sponge crab.

A female crab from which the egg pouch or bunion has been removed, or an egg-bearing female crab known as the sponge crab may be imported into Maryland from another state by a dealer or crab processing plant:
If accompanied by a bill of sale or bill of lading from the jurisdiction of origin; and
Only during the time period specified in the public notice issued in accordance with §C of this regulation.
Public Notice.

In consultation with blue crab industry advisory groups, the Department shall issue a public notice to establish a time period of 71 consecutive days when a female crab from which the egg pouch or bunion has been removed, or an egg-bearing female crab known as the sponge crab may be imported into Maryland from another state.
The import time period may not begin prior to April 10 or end after July 20.
The public notice shall be published on the Department’s website by April 1 of each year.

The Secretary shall make a reasonable effort to disseminate a public notice issued under this section through various other media so that an affected individual has a reasonable opportunity to be informed.
A violation of the restrictions set by the Secretary in accordance with section is a violation of this regulation.

section.heading: Recreational Crabbing Licenses — Chesapeake Bay and Its Tidal Tributaries.

para.text: Recreational Crabbing License.

Except as provided in §E of this regulation, an individual who catches or attempts to catch crabs for recreational purposes in the waters of the Chesapeake Bay and its tidal tributaries shall pay the fee and obtain a recreational crabbing license in order to use the following gear to catch crabs:
Trotline;
Collapsible traps or net rings;
Up to ten eel pots for catching the individual's own bait, which are:
Clearly labeled with the individual's name;
Not placed in a buoy free channel as listed in Regulation .07H of this chapter or COMAR 08.02.05.08F; and
Used only for catching eels; and
Seines.

The annual fee for a recreational crabbing license to catch or attempt to catch crabs for recreational purposes from the waters of the Chesapeake Bay and its tidal tributaries with the gear specified in §A(1) of this regulation is:
For a Maryland resident — $5;
For a Maryland resident, in possession of a Maryland Chesapeake Bay and coastal sport fishing license or a resident consolidated senior sport fishing license — $2;
For a nonresident — $10.
An individual who has purchased a recreational crabbing license shall have the license in possession when:
Engaged in crabbing for recreational purposes with the gear listed under §A(1) of this regulation; or

In possession of more crabs than provided for in the daily catch limits set forth in Regulation .10A(2)(a), A(3)(a) and (b), and A(4)(a) of this chapter and not on a boat that has been licensed as a recreational crab boat.
Recreational Crabbing Boat License.
A recreational crabbing boat license authorizes an individual to use the following gear to catch or attempt to catch crabs in the licensed boat in the Chesapeake Bay and its tidal tributaries:
Trotline; and
Collapsible traps or net rings.

The annual fee for a recreational crabbing boat license to catch or attempt to catch crabs for recreational purposes from the waters of the Chesapeake Bay and its tidal tributaries with the gear specified in §B(1) of this regulation is $15.
To the recreational crabbing boat licensee, the Department shall issue:
A recreational crabbing boat decal; and
A complimentary recreational crabbing license.
Except as provided in §B(5) of this regulation, the recreational crabbing boat decal:
Shall be permanently affixed and displayed on either side of the forward half of the vessel for which issued;
Is not transferable; and
Shall, when displayed, exempt all persons aboard from the requirement of possessing an individual license to crab recreationally.

Exemption for Crabbing Boat Decals. If the crabbing boat decal is not permanently affixed to the vessel, all persons aboard are exempt from the requirement of possessing an individual license to crab recreationally only if:
The individual who purchased the crabbing boat decal is present on the vessel;
The individual who purchased the crabbing boat decal is in possession of the proof of purchase issued by the Department; and
The crabbing boat decal was purchased within the previous 10 calendar days.
Complimentary Recreational Crabbing License.
The Department shall issue a complimentary recreational crabbing license to an individual who purchases a:
Recreational crabbing boat license; or
Chesapeake Bay and coastal sport fishing boat license in accordance with Natural Resources Article, §4-745(d)(2), Annotated Code of Maryland.
The individual issued the complimentary recreational crabbing license has the same restrictions as an individual with a recreational crabbing license.
The recreational crabbing boat license and the complimentary recreational crabbing license count as a single license for the individual who purchases the recreational crabbing boat license.
Private Waterfront Property Crab Pot Registration.
Only a person who owns or leases private property along the shore of the Chesapeake Bay and its tidal tributaries may obtain a private waterfront property crab pot registration.

A person who owns or leases private property along the shore of the Chesapeake Bay and its tidal tributaries shall obtain a private waterfront property crab pot registration in order to use a crab pot from the person’s property.
There is no fee for a private waterfront property crab pot registration.

Exceptions. An individual who catches or attempts to catch crabs for recreational purposes in the waters of the Chesapeake Bay and its tidal tributaries is not required to have a recreational crabbing license if the individual:
Uses any of the following gear:
A dipnet;
A handline; or
Up to two crab pots, if qualified to use crab pots as set forth in Regulation .07D of this chapter;
Is assisting an individual who has a recreational crabbing license; or
Is crabbing for recreational purposes from a boat that has been licensed by the Department as a recreational crabbing boat.
General.
A recreational crabbing license, recreational crabbing boat license, or private waterfront property crab pot registration is valid for 365 days following the date of issuance.
A recreational crabbing license, recreational crabbing boat license, or private waterfront property crab pot registration may be obtained from any authorized agent of the Department.

The Department may designate a person engaged in a commercial enterprise as an agent to sell recreational crabbing licenses, recreational crabbing boat licenses, or issue private waterfront property crab pot registrations.
An agent may retain:
50 cents for each recreational crabbing license issued by the agent; and
$1.50 for each recreational crabbing boat license issued by the agent.

section.heading: Recreational Crabbing Catch and Possession Limits — Chesapeake Bay and its Tidal Tributaries.

para.text: Daily Catch and Possession Limits.

An individual exempt from the licensing requirements of Regulation .09 of this chapter is considered an unlicensed individual and may not exceed the catch and possession limits for an unlicensed individual.
Daily catch and possession limits for individuals harvesting crabs from shore or from crab pots.

tr.td: 1 dozen soft crabs,1 dozen male peeler crabs, or a combination of 1 dozen soft crabs and male peeler crabs

1 bushel male hard crabs if storing crabs in a bushel
6 dozen male hard crabs if storing crabs in any container other than a bushel
2 dozen soft crabs, 2 dozen male peeler crabs, or a combination of 2 dozen soft crabs and male peeler crabs

para.text: Daily catch and possession boat limits for a vessel without a recreational crabbing boat license.

tr.td: (a) One unlicensed individual on board an unlicensed vessel
1 dozen soft crabs,1 dozen male peeler crabs, or a combination of 1 dozen soft crabs and male peeler crabs
(b) Two or more unlicensed individuals on board an unlicensed vessel
1 dozen soft crabs, 1 dozen male peeler crabs, or a combination of 1 dozen soft crabs and male peeler crabs
(c) One licensed individual or one licensed individual accompanied by any number of unlicensed individuals on board an unlicensed vessel

1 bushel male hard crabs if storing crabs in a bushel
6 dozen male hard crabs if storing crabs in any container other than a bushel
2 dozen soft crabs, 2 dozen male peeler crabs, or a combination of 2 dozen soft crabs and male peeler crabs
(d) Two or more licensed individuals or two or more licensed individuals accompanied by any number of unlicensed individuals on board an unlicensed vessel

2 bushels male hard crabs if storing crabs in bushels
12 dozen male hard crabs if storing crabs in any container other than a bushel
2 dozen soft crabs, 2 dozen male peeler crabs, or a combination of 2 dozen soft crabs and male peeler crabs

para.text: Daily catch and possession boat limits for a vessel with a recreational crabbing boat license.

tr.td: (a) One or more unlicensed individuals on board a licensed vessel

1 bushel male hard crabs if storing crabs in a bushel
6 dozen male hard crabs if storing crabs in any container other than a bushel
2 dozen soft crabs,2 dozen male peeler crabs, or a combination of 2 dozen soft crabs and male peeler crabs
(b) One licensed individual on board a licensed vessel

1 bushel male hard crabs if storing crabs in a bushel
6 dozen male hard crabs if storing crabs in any container other than a bushel
2 dozen soft crabs, 2 dozen male peeler crabs, or a combination of 2 dozen soft crabs and male peeler crabs
(c) An individual who purchased a recreational crabbing boat license accompanied by any number of unlicensed individuals on board a licensed vessel

1 bushel male hard crabs if storing crabs in a bushel
6 dozen male hard crabs if storing crabs in any container other than a bushel
2 dozen soft crabs, 2 dozen male peeler crabs, or a combination of 2 dozen soft crabs and male peeler crabs
(d) Two or more licensed individuals accompanied by any number of unlicensed individuals on board a licensed vessel

2 bushels male hard crabs if storing crabs in bushels
12 dozen male hard crabs if storing crabs in any container other than a bushel

2 dozen soft crabs, 2 dozen male peeler crabs, or a combination of 2 dozen soft crabs and male peeler crabs
The catch limit is a bushel per licensed individual when using a bushel to hold male crabs. When not using a bushel the catch limit is 6 dozen male hard crabs per licensed individual.
(e) One licensed individual, who is not the owner of the licensed vessel, accompanied by any number of unlicensed individuals on board a licensed vessel

2 bushels male hard crabs if storing crabs in bushels
12 dozen male hard crabs if storing crabs in any container other than a bushel

2 dozen soft crabs, 2 dozen male peeler crabs, or a combination of 2 dozen soft crabs and male peeler crabs
The catch limit is a bushel per licensed individual when using a bushel to hold male crabs. When not using a bushel the catch limit is 6 dozen male hard crabs per licensed individual.

para.text: Female Hard Crabs and Female Peelers.
Except as provided in §B(2) of this regulation, an individual may not catch or possess female hard crabs or female peelers.
Exception.
Female crabs are accompanied by a bill of sale; and
Individual is not catching or attempting to catch crabs.

section.heading: Season and Time for Catching Crabs.

para.text: Commercial.
An individual licensed to catch crabs for sale may remove crabs from commercial gear in the Chesapeake Bay and its tidal tributaries only during the following time periods:
Trotlines:
Except as provided in §A(1)(a)(iii) of this regulation, between 1 hour before sunrise to 9 hours after sunrise during the period May through September;
Between 1/2 hour before sunrise and 9½ hours after sunrise during April, October, November, and December; and
Between 2 hours before sunrise to 9 hours after sunrise on Memorial Day, Juneteenth National Independence Day, July 4, Labor Day, and the day immediately preceding each of those holidays; and
Crab Scrapes:
Except as provided in §A(1)(b)(iii) of this regulation, between 1 hour before sunrise to 9 hours after sunrise during the period May through September;
Between sunrise and 10 hours after sunrise during April and October; and
Between 2 hours before sunrise to 9 hours after sunrise on Memorial Day, Juneteenth National Independence Day, July 4, Labor Day, and the day immediately preceding each of those holidays; and
Crab pots, bank traps, channel pounds, collapsible traps, net rings, handlines, dip nets, and pound nets:
Except as provided in §A(1)(c)(ii) of this regulation, between 1/2 hour before sunrise to 7½ hours after sunrise; and
Between 1½ hours before sunrise to 7½ hours after sunrise on Memorial Day, Juneteenth National Independence Day, July 4, Labor Day, and the day immediately preceding each of those holidays.
A person may not catch crabs using a crab scrape from October 31 to April 14, inclusive.
An individual licensed to catch crabs for sale may set or place overboard scrapes only during the following time periods:
Except as provided in §A(3)(c) of this regulation, between 1 hour before sunrise to 9 hours after sunrise during the period May through September;
Between sunrise and 10 hours after sunrise during April and October; and
Between 2 hours before sunrise to 9 hours after sunrise on Memorial Day, Juneteenth National Independence Day, July 4, Labor Day, and the day immediately preceding each of those holidays.
Crab Pot Set Times. Crab pots may only be set:
During the time periods established in §A(1)(c) of this regulation; or
If already onboard a boat at the end of the time periods established in §A(1)(c) of this regulation, for 1 hour after the end of the time periods established in §A(1)(c) of this regulation.
Time limits specified in this regulation are not applicable to the fishing of bank traps before May 1.
Recreational.
Except as provided in §B(2) of this regulation, a person may not set any recreational crabbing gear or catch crabs for recreational purposes during:
May through September between:
5 p.m. and 1/2 hour before sunrise in the main Chesapeake Bay; and
Sunset and 1/2 hour before sunrise in tidal tributaries of the Chesapeake Bay; and
April, October, November, and December between:
5 p.m. and 1/2 hour after sunrise in the main Chesapeake Bay; and
Sunset and 1/2 hour after sunrise in tidal tributaries of the Chesapeake Bay.
Crab pots, dip nets, and handlines. At all times during the recreational season for crabbing, a person may use:
Crab pots on private property that have been registered in accordance with Regulation .09 of this chapter;
Dip nets; or
Handlines.
A person may not catch blue crabs in the Chesapeake Bay and its tidal tributaries from December 16 through March 31, inclusive.

section.heading: Special Regulations for Crabbing in Worcester County.

para.text: Structural Requirements of Crab Pots. Notwithstanding Regulation .07A and B of this chapter, a crab pot set in the coastal bays of the Atlantic Ocean and their tidal tributaries shall have one unobstructed 2-5/16 inch cull ring on a side panel of the upper compartment and one 2-5/16 inch cull ring on a panel at the lower compartment of the crab pot. The cull ring is not required in a crab pot constructed with unstretched mesh measuring less than 1½ inches or at least 2 inches on each side.
Daily Catch Limits.
Commercial. The daily catch limit in the coastal bays of the Atlantic Ocean and their tidal tributaries is 25 bushels, 16 lugs, or 10 barrels per commercial boat.
Recreational. The daily catch limit in the waters of the coastal bays of the Atlantic Ocean and their tidal tributaries is:
1 bushel per individual if storing crabs in a bushel;
6 dozen crabs per individual if storing crabs in any container other than a bushel;
2 bushels per boat if two or more individuals are on the boat and storing crabs in bushels; and
12 dozen crabs per boat if two or more individuals are on the boat and storing crabs in any container other than bushels.
Seasons for Catching Crabs.
Commercial. A person licensed to catch crabs for sale may not catch crabs in the coastal bays of the Atlantic Ocean and their tidal tributaries between October 31 and April 1.
Recreational. A person may not catch crabs for recreational purposes in the coastal bays of the Atlantic Ocean and their tidal tributaries between December 31 and April 1.

Commercial Daily Time Restrictions. A person licensed to catch crabs for sale may remove crabs from commercial gear and set or retrieve crab pots in the coastal bays of the Atlantic Ocean and their tidal tributaries only during the following time periods:
Between sunrise and 8½ hours after sunrise during April and October;
Except as provided in §D(3) of this regulation, between ½ hour before sunrise to 8 hours after sunrise during the period May through September; and
Between 1½ hours before sunrise to 8 hours after sunrise on Memorial Day, Juneteenth National Independence Day, July 4, Labor Day, and the day immediately preceding each of those holidays.
Gear Restrictions. A person may not catch crabs in the coastal bays of the Atlantic Ocean and their tidal tributaries by scrape.
Landing Provision. Crabs caught in the waters of Worcester County may be landed out of the State.

section.heading: Commercial Harvest of Crabs from Finfish Gear.

para.text: Notwithstanding Regulations .01—.07 of this chapter, an individual licensed to harvest both crabs and finfish for commercial purposes may catch crabs from pound nets.
The harvest and possession of crabs from a pound net is:
Prohibited on any day during which a licensee is otherwise prohibited from harvesting crabs as provided in Regulation .14 of this chapter;
Restricted to the seasons and times provided in Regulations .11 and .12 of this chapter;
Restricted by the size limits provided in Regulation .14 of this chapter;
Restricted to a maximum of 2 bushels or 1 lug of male crabs per licensee per day; and
Restricted to the daily maximum number of female crabs allowed by the individual's license type.
Notwithstanding COMAR 08.02.25.04, a licensee may only harvest or possess crabs from a pound net or combination of pound nets registered in the licensee's name.
Recreational.

Except for crab pots from private property, dipnets, or handlines, a person may not set any crabbing gear or catch crabs for recreational purposes on Wednesdays in the Chesapeake Bay and its tidal tributaries.
When a State or federal holiday falls on a Wednesday or Thursday, recreational crabbing is permitted on the Wednesday of that week.
An individual may not offer to sell or sell crabs that were caught for recreational purposes.
An individual may not knowingly buy or offer to buy crabs which were caught for recreational purposes.

An individual licensed to provide services as a fishing guide or to fish recreationally in the Chesapeake Bay and its tidal tributaries may possess any number of soft crabs or male peeler crabs for the purposes of fishing.
An individual licensed to catch crabs for commercial purposes:
May catch crabs for recreational purposes with recreational crabbing gear without paying the fee for recreational crabbing set forth in Regulation .09 of this chapter; and
Has the same restrictions as an individual with a recreational crabbing license when engaged in recreational crabbing activities.
Commercial — General.
A person licensed to catch crabs for sale may not set or retrieve gear or catch crabs for commercial purposes in the Chesapeake Bay and its tidal tributaries on Sundays and Mondays unless the person:
Declares intent under §C of this regulation;
Is granted an alternate day off under §D of this regulation;
Is operating as a licensee's authorized user on the vessel designated in accordance with Natural Resources Article, §4-701, Annotated Code of Maryland; or
Is assisting as an unlicensed crew member on another licensee's vessel.
A person who is granted an alternate day off under §D of this regulation may not set or retrieve gear or catch crabs for commercial purposes on the alternate day off.

The vessel of a person licensed to catch crabs for sale may not be used to set or retrieve gear or catch crabs for commercial purposes on the day or days on which the vessel's owner may not set or retrieve gear or catch crabs for commercial purposes.

A person licensed to catch crabs for commercial purposes, who declares under §C(1) of this regulation, may set or retrieve gear or catch crabs for commercial purposes on a Sunday or Monday of a particular week if:
A State or federal holiday falls on the Sunday or Monday, or the immediately preceding Saturday; or
The Sunday or Monday precedes a State or federal holiday that falls on a Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday, or Friday of the particular week.
Mature female hard crabs shall be kept in separate bushels, lugs, or barrels from male hard crabs or peeler crabs.
Mature female hard crabs on board a vessel shall be stored in the same type of containers of similar dimensions.
Male hard crabs on board a vessel shall be stored in the same type of containers of similar dimensions.
Except as specified in §F(2) of this regulation, an individual licensed to catch crabs for commercial purposes may not catch or possess in the Chesapeake Bay and its tidal tributaries more than:
Six mature female hard crabs per container smaller than a barrel of male crabs; or
13 mature female hard crabs per barrel of male crabs.

Beginning in 2010, an individual with a limited crab harvester (LCC) license will be considered as limited crab harvester frozen license status, as specified in §F(2)(b) of this regulation, if that license is not designated as a:
Limited crab harvester active license; or
Limited crab harvester male only license.
The commercial female crab daily catch limit shall be determined by the license type based on the abundance target for spawning age crabs recommended by the Chesapeake Bay Stock Assessment Committee.

Except as provided in §B(11) of this regulation, an individual licensed to catch crabs for commercial purposes may not harvest or possess more mature female hard crabs daily than the catch limit specified by the individual's license type.

Except as provided in §B(11) of this regulation, more than two licensees' daily catch limits from 1 day may not be harvested from, carried on, or possessed on a vessel while the licensees are on board.
An individual may possess and transport crabs harvested from the waters of the Potomac River or Virginia if:
The individual is not engaged in harvesting crabs in Maryland waters while the crabs harvested in the waters of the Potomac River or Virginia are on board the vessel; and
The individual is in possession of a Virginia commercial crab harvester license or Potomac River Fisheries Commission commercial license.
A float used for holding or shedding peelers shall have a base that is a minimum of 16 square feet.
An individual commercially harvesting crabs aboard a vessel may only have crabs that are commercially harvested on board.
Closed Day Declaration of Intent.

A person licensed to catch crabs for sale and who wishes to set or retrieve gear or catch crabs on one of the required days off in §B(1) of this regulation shall declare that person's intent to set or retrieve gear or catch crabs in the Chesapeake Bay and its tidal tributaries for commercial purposes on one of the required days off as specified in §B(1) of this regulation.

Display of Declaration. The letters for the abbreviation of the day off shall be identified and displayed on the vessel and shall be painted or firmly attached to the port side near the stern of the vessel as follows:
The letters shall be positioned in such a manner as to be clearly visible to persons in passing boats;
The letters shall be plain vertical block characters of not less than 3 inches in height and shall contrast with the color of the background;
The letters "SUN" shall be displayed as the abbreviation for Sundays; and
The letters "MON" shall be displayed as the abbreviation for Monday.

A person licensed to catch crabs for sale who declares a day off under §C(1) of this regulation shall declare a Sunday or Monday day off only at the time of license renewal or issuance on forms provided by the Department.
Alternate Closed Day.

A person licensed to catch crabs for sale may apply to the Department for an alternate to the closed days specified in §B(1) of this regulation. The Department may grant a licensee's request for an alternate closed day if the licensee demonstrates the:
Imposition of substantial hardship on the licensee's exercise of religion by observing one of the closed days specified in §B(1) of this regulation; and
Absence of substantial hardship on the licensee's exercise of religion by observing the alternate closed day requested in the application.
An alternate closed day shall be displayed on the vessel in the manner set forth in §C(2) of this regulation using the first three letters of the day of the week.
A licensee who is granted an alternate closed day may set gear and catch crabs on the closed days specified in §B(1) of this regulation.

A person licensed to catch crabs for sale who declares a day off under §D(1) of this regulation shall declare an alternate day off only at the time of license renewal or issuance on forms provided by the Department.
Notwithstanding Natural Resources Article, §4-809, Annotated Code of Maryland, a person may not:
Catch or possess more than 6 hard crabs per container smaller than a barrel or 13 hard crabs per barrel which measure less than the minimum size specified in these regulations;
Possess hard crabs imported from another State which:
Measure less than 5 inches across the shell from tip to tip of the spike;
Do not comply with the tolerance limits of the jurisdiction of origin;
Are not accompanied by a bill of sale or bill of lading from the jurisdiction of origin; and
Were not caught in full compliance with the laws of the jurisdiction of origin;

From April 1 through July 14, catch or possess a hard crab which measures less than 5 inches across the shell from tip to tip of the spike, from the waters of the Chesapeake Bay and its tidal tributaries, except that the minimum size of crabs does not apply to mature female crabs, identified by the apron;

After July 14, catch or possess a hard crab which measures less than 5¼ inches across the shell from tip to tip of the spike from the waters of the Chesapeake Bay and its tidal tributaries, except that the minimum size of crabs does not apply to mature female crabs, identified by the apron;

Catch or possess a hard crab which measures less than 5 inches across the shell from tip to tip of the spike from the waters of Worcester County, except that the minimum size of crabs does not apply to mature female crabs, identified by the apron;
Except as provided in §E(7) of this regulation, catch or possess more than 10 peeler crabs per bushel or more than 20 per float which are:
Less than 3-1/4 inches across the shell from tip to tip of the spike during the period from April 1 through July 14; and
Less than 3-1/2 inches across the shell from tip to tip of the spike during the period from July 15 through December 15;

Catch or possess more than 10 female peeler crabs per bushel or more than 20 per float which are less than 3½ inches across the shell from tip to tip of the spike in the Chesapeake Bay and its tidal tributaries during the period from April 1, 2015 through December 15, 2015; or
Catch or possess more than one soft crab per 2 dozen soft crabs which is less than 3½ inches across the shell from tip to tip of the spike.
Limited Crab Harvester.
Latent Effort Limited Crab Harvester License.

A limited crab harvester (LCC) authorization of a tidal fish license that has no reported crab harvest between January 1, 2004 and December 15, 2008 on reports submitted to the Department by January 30, 2009, shall be determined to be a latent effort limited crab harvester license, except for those licenses specified in §F(1)(b) of this regulation.
Exceptions to Latent Effort Designation. The following are exceptions to the latent effort designation:
An LCC authorization received through the apprenticeship program;
An LCC authorization received through a permanent license transfer between August 1, 2006 and July 8, 2009;
An LCC authorization assigned to an individual who provides appropriate documentation of active military service during the period January 1, 2004 and January 30, 2009;
An LCC assigned to an individual who completed a successful female bushel limit hardship appeal in 2008; and
An LCC assigned to an individual who currently resides and has resided for at least 5 years on an island in the State that is at least 3 miles from the mainland.
Latent Effort Limited Crab Harvester Status.

An individual with a license that has been determined to be a latent effort license as described in §F(1) of this regulation is required to have declared their LCC license as a limited crab harvester — male only as described in §F(2)(b) of this regulation.
An individual with a limited crab harvester license — male only status:
Shall only harvest male crabs beginning on April 1, 2010;
May not harvest females at any time regardless of the blue crab population target level being achieved for 3 consecutive years;
Shall renew the license annually in accordance with the schedule and fees designated for a LCC authorization in Natural Resources Article, §4-701, Annotated Code of Maryland; and

May apply to the Department for a permanent or temporary transfer of the license through a family, business, or beneficiary transfer as described in Natural Resources Article, §4-701, Annotated Code of Maryland.
The latent effort license status may not be modified after declaration even if the license has been transferred to a new owner.
Conditions for using an LCC male only authorization as one of the required authorizations to upgrade to an unlimited tidal fish authorization are described in COMAR 08.02.01.05I.

Notwithstanding Natural Resources Article, §4-701, Annotated Code of Maryland, any LCC which was previously frozen due to latent license status as described in §F(1) of this regulation will not be required to pay the authorization fee for the 2012 commercial crabbing season.
Public Notice.

The Secretary may establish or modify catch limits or modify seasons for blue crabs in order to implement the Chesapeake Bay Blue Crab Fishery Management Plan by issuing a public notice on the Department's website.
The public notice shall state its effective hour and date and shall be published on the Department's website at least 48 hours in advance of the effective hour and date.

The Secretary shall make a reasonable effort to disseminate a public notice issued under this section through various other media so that an affected person has a reasonable opportunity to be informed.
A violation of the restrictions set by the Secretary in accordance with this section is a violation of this regulation.
This regulation applies to any trip to catch crabs offered by a tidal fish licensee to an individual or individuals for any form of compensation.
Any individual receiving compensation from customers for any trip to catch crabs shall be in possession of the appropriate federal licenses.

An individual who, in accordance with Natural Resources Article, §4-701, Annotated Code of Maryland, is licensed as a fishing guide, is licensed as a master fishing guide or operates a vessel for a master fishing guide and possesses a valid commercial crabbing authorization:
May carry customers during a commercial crabbing trip;
Shall follow all commercial crabbing rules;
May not count customers as crew members;
May sell their catch to a seafood dealer or, if licensed as a seafood dealer in accordance with Natural Resources Article, §4-701, Annotated Code of Maryland, to a customer;
Shall report their catch in accordance with COMAR 08.02.13.06; and
Shall be penalized for any violation of statute or regulation in accordance with COMAR 08.02.13.03
Crabbing Charters.

Definition. In this chapter, “crabbing charter” means any guided trip for the purpose of catching crabs recreationally, offered by an individual who, in accordance with Natural Resources Article, §4-701, Annotated Code of Maryland, is licensed as a fishing guide or master fishing guide, or operates a vessel for a master fishing guide.
Crabbing Charter Decal.
Prior to operating a crabbing charter, a fishing guide shall obtain a crabbing charter decal.
Except as provided in §D(2)(c) of this regulation, a decal issued for a crabbing charter:
Shall be permanently affixed and displayed on either side of the forward half of the vessel for which issued;
Is not transferable;
Shall, when displayed, exempt all persons aboard from the requirement of possessing an individual license to crab recreationally; and
Is valid for the current commercial license year.

Exemption for Crabbing Charter Decals. If the crabbing charter decal is not permanently affixed to the vessel, all persons aboard are exempt from the requirement of possessing an individual license to crab recreationally only if:
The individual who purchased the crabbing charter decal is present on the vessel;
The individual who purchased the crabbing charter decal is in possession of the proof of purchase issued by the Department; and
The crabbing charter decal was purchased within the previous 10 calendar days.
A crabbing charter:

May only be offered by an individual licensed as a fishing guide or a master fishing guide, or who operates a vessel for a master fishing guide in accordance with Natural Resources Article, §4-701, Annotated Code of Maryland;
Shall have at least one customer on board;
May not harvest female hard crabs or female peelers from the Chesapeake Bay and its tidal tributaries; and
Shall comply with the recreational season, times, size limits, and gear restrictions established in this chapter for a licensed recreational crabber.
Crabs caught on a crabbing charter may not be sold.
Catch Limit. A crabbing charter with one or more customers on board may not catch more than two bushels of:
Male hard crabs and two dozen soft crabs or male peeler crabs from the Chesapeake Bay and its tidal tributaries; or
Crabs from the Atlantic Ocean and its coastal bays.
Reporting. Crabs harvested on a crabbing charter shall be reported on forms provided by the Department and in the time specified by the Department.
Any violation of statute or regulation shall be penalized in accordance with COMAR 08.02.13.08.
